booklist.title: Acts and Letters of the Apostles2019-20
People of the Promised Land I2018-19

LESSON/2020_1?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth." – Genesis 1:1

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. What from the notes, lecture, or thoughts about the Genesis study impacted you most in the past week?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read Genesis 1:1-2.
God created the heavens and the earth.

questions.questionText: 3. What do these verses reveal about God and creation?
4. What most intrigues you in these verses?

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read Genesis 1:3-13.
God began creating earth's attributes.

questions.questionText: 5. What did God create and name on the first through third days?
6. What are the possible ways to define "day"? Which one seems most plausible to you? (See Exodus 20:11; 2 Peter 3:8 and other Scriptures you may know for help.)
7. What phrases are repeated?
8. What do you learn about God and creation from these verses?

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read Genesis 1:14-25.
God called the lights and animals into existence.

questions.questionText: 9. How did God fill the earth on the fourth through sixth days?
10. How does the light in verse 3 compare with the lights on the fourth day?
11. What conclusions do you make from the repeated phrase "and God saw that it was good"?
12. What makes it hard to believe there is a Creator God?

five.title:
FIFTH DAY: Read Psalm 148 and Job 38-40 with Genesis 1:1-25 in mind.
All creation is called to praise God.

questions.questionText: 13. What is your takeaway about God and creation?
14. What are the implications for your daily life based on these truths?
15. What is the most surprising or challenging thing you discovered this week?

LESSON/2020_2?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "Then God said, 'Let us make mankind in our image, in our likeness, so that they may rule over the fish in the sea and the birds in the sky, over the livestock and all the wild animals, and over all the creatures that move along the ground." – Genesis 1:26

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. What from the notes, lecture, group sharing or personal study impacted you most in the past week?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read Genesis 1:26-31.
God created mankind in His image on the sixth day.

questions.questionText: 3. What distinguishes humanity from the rest of creation?
4. What does it mean to be created in God's image?
5. What do you learn about the identity and purpose of humanity? How does that help, encourage or challenge you?
6. What commands did God give humanity? What is our responsibility today in view of these commands?

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read Genesis 2:1-3.
God rested from His "very good" work of creation on the seventh day.

questions.questionText: 7. What do you notice about the seventh day?
8. What does "God rested" mean?
9. What do you learn about work and rest? How could you apply this to your life?

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read Genesis 2:4-25.
God personally made Adam and Eve for life in Eden.

questions.questionText: 10. Which details about Adam and Eve and life in the garden stand out to you and why?
11. What commands did God give to Adam and Eve? Why were they given?
12. What can you know about God from creation?

five.title:
FIFTH DAY: Read Genesis 2:4-25.
Humans are created to glorify God and to work together for good.

questions.questionText: 13. What conclusions do you draw about God's purpose for marriage?
14. What do you learn about God? About humanity and our purpose?
15. How does what you learned impact the way you view your current circumstances?
16. How did these passages impact your thinking about how God's view of every human life offers hope and establishes priorities?

LESSON/2020_3?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "So the Lord God said to the serpent, 'Because you have done this … I will put enmity between you and the woman, and between your offspring and hers; he will crush your head, and you will strike his heel.' " – Genesis 3:14-15

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. What from the notes, lecture, group sharing or personal study impacted you most in the past week?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read Genesis 3:1-5.
The serpent tempted Eve to sin.

questions.questionText: 3. What do you notice about the conversation between the serpent and Eve? (See Genesis 2:15-17.)
4. The serpent is identified with Satan. (See Revelation 12:9.) What characteristics does he display in these verses?
5. How do temptations cause people to question God's character? What role do our desires play in temptation?
6. a. What have you learned about temptation?
6. b. What temptations do you currently face?

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read Genesis 3:6-13.
Adam and Eve disobeyed God.

questions.questionText: 7. How did Adam and Eve rationalize or justify their sin?
8. What immediate effects occurred for Adam and Eve personally and in their relationship with God? What died?
9. What stands out to you about God's response?

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read Genesis 3:14-19.
God explained the consequences for sin.

questions.questionText: 10. How did life change for Adam and Eve because of their disobedience?
11. What promise did God make? What is the significance of this promise? (See Isaiah 25:6-12; 53:4-5; Romans 16:19-20; and 2 Peter 3:9 for interpretation of the promise.)
12. How do people currently experience the realities of the judgment and promise given to Adam and Eve? (See 1 Corinthians 15:21-22 for help or any other verses.)

five.title:
FIFTH DAY: Read Genesis 3:20-24.
The Lord God banished Adam and Eve from the Garden of Eden.

questions.questionText: 13. What actions did God take and why?
14. What do you learn about God?
15. What attribute of God stands out most to you in Genesis 3? How do you see that attribute displayed in the world today?

LESSON/2020_4?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "If you do what is right, will you not be accepted? But if you do not do what is right, sin is crouching at your door; it desires to have you, but you must rule over it." – Genesis 4:7

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. What from the notes, lecture, group sharing or personal study impacted you most in the past week?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read Genesis 4:1-7.
The Lord responded to Cain and Abel and their offerings.

questions.questionText: 3. Compare and contrast Cain and Abel and their offerings. What stands out to you?
4. Why did the Lord accept Abel and his offering but not Cain and his offering? (See Hebrews 11:4.)
5. a. Name some factors that contributed to Cain's anger.
5. b. How do you react when someone suggests you are wrong? Why?
6. What do you learn about God from His interaction with Cain?

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read Genesis 4:8-12.
Cain killed Abel and was cursed by the Lord.

questions.questionText: 7. Describe Cain's actions that culminated in killing his brother Abel.
8. What do you notice about the Lord's conversation with Cain?
9. a. Why is it difficult to confess and accept responsibility for sinful actions and reactions?
9. b. What impact could victory in this area have on your relationships?
10. From Genesis 4:1-12, what truths do we need to know about temptation and sin?

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read Genesis 4:13-16.
Cain went out from the Lord's presence.

questions.questionText: 11. What do you learn about Cain from his responses to the Lord?
12. How do you respond when confronted about your sin? What does this reveal about your heart?
13. How does God's response to Cain comfort or challenge you?

five.title:
FIFTH DAY: Read Genesis 4:17-26.
Cain's descendants increased, and Seth was born.

questions.questionText: 14. What progress did Cain's descendants make?
15. What do you observe about the character of Cain's descendants and their relationships with God and one another?
16. What hope was there in Seth's birth and for all who "called on the name of the Lord"?
17. What warning or comfort do you want to remember from this chapter?
18. How did this week's study impact your thinking about temptations surrounding you and the unexpected consequences of sin?

LESSON/2020_5?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "God said to Noah, 'I am going to put an end to all people, for the earth is filled with violence because of them. I am surely going to destroy both them and the earth.' " – Genesis 6:13

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. What from the notes, lecture, group sharing or personal study impacted you most in the past week?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read Genesis 5.
Adam's descendants from Seth through Noah are summarized.

questions.questionText: 3. What do you learn from the repeated phrases about God and mankind?
4. What stands out to you about Enoch? (See Hebrews 11:5-6; Jude 1:14-15.)
5. a. What does it mean to walk faithfully with God?
5. b. How would you describe your walk with God?
6. How does this chapter inform your thinking about life, death and the afterlife?

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read Genesis 6-7.
The Lord decreed judgment for evil but favored Noah.

questions.questionText: 7. Describe the world at that time and the Lord's response.
8. How did Noah find favor in the eyes of the Lord?
9. a. What do you learn about Noah and his character?
9. b. What would need to change in your life for you to have a reputation like Noah's?

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read Genesis 6-7.
The Lord commanded Noah to build and fill the ark.

questions.questionText: 10. What stands out in God's instructions, warning and promises to Noah?
11. a. What do these verses say about Noah's response to God?
11. b. What is your response to God's instructions, warnings and promises concerning judgment and salvation?
12. What is God asking you to do at this time in your life? How are you responding?

five.title:
FIFTH DAY: Read Genesis 7.
Every living thing died except those in the ark.

questions.questionText: 13. What stands out to you about God's judgment? What questions does God's judgment raise for you?
14. What does the flood teach you about faith in God's Word and God's faithfulness to His Word?
15. How is the flood an encouragement to some and a warning to others? Which is it to you?
16. How does this passage impact the way you interact with others?
17. What do you learn from these chapters about God's patience and mercy before judgment?
18. Homiletics for group and administrative leaders: Genesis 5-7

LESSON/2020_6?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "I establish my covenant with you: Never again will all life be destroyed by the waters of a flood; never again will there be a flood to destroy the earth." – Genesis 9:11

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. What from the notes, lecture, group sharing or personal study kept coming to mind this week?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read Genesis 8:1-14.
God remembered Noah and ended the Flood.

questions.questionText: 3. What do you notice about Noah's actions while he waited for the earth to dry up?
4. a. Where is the meaning of "God remembered" demonstrated by God's actions in these verses?
4. b. What truths about God and Noah do you want to remember?
5. What are you currently waiting on God to do? How does this passage encourage or challenge you while waiting?

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read Genesis 8:15-22.
Noah exited the ark and built an altar to offer sacrifices to God.

questions.questionText: 6. a. What instructions and promises did God give?
6. b. How did Noah respond? Why?
7. a. What sacrifice ultimately pleased God? (See John 12:27-33; Romans 3:25-26; 1 Peter 2:21-24.)
7. b. What sacrifices can you offer in response to God today? (See Proverbs 21:3; Hosea 6:6; Micah 6:8; John 15:13; Romans 12:1-2; and Hebrews 13:15-16 to expand your thinking beyond this passage.)
8. List the attributes or characteristics of God in this passage. Which one is most meaningful to you?

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read Genesis 9:1-7.
God gave blessings and instructions for filling the earth.

questions.questionText: 9. List the commands God gave Noah. How do these compare with the commands He gave in Eden (Genesis 1:28-30)?
10. How are God's commands concerning people and animals reflected in your attitudes, actions or culture?
11. What do you learn about God's desires for humanity and the value of human life that challenges your interactions with others? How might this change your prayers for our world today?

five.title:
FIFTH DAY: Read Genesis 9:8-17.
God gave an unconditional covenant to humanity and all creation.

questions.questionText: 12. What are the details of God's covenant with Noah and his descendants, including us? (See also Genesis 8:21-22.)
13. How does the covenant shape your thinking about God and His creation?
14. a. What is the sign of God's covenant? What does the sign signify?
14. b. What reasons do we have to believe that God is able to keep His covenant?
15. How does this week's study help you with questions you or those around you ask about God's plan for the world?
16. Homiletics for group and administrative leaders: Genesis 8:1-9:17

LESSON/2020_7?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "But the Lord came down to see the city and the tower the people were building." – Genesis 11:5

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. What from last week's verses, lecture, notes or discussion influenced your thoughts or actions this week?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read Genesis 9:18-23.
Noah's nakedness was revealed by Ham and covered by Shem and Japheth.

questions.questionText: 3. Describe the actions of Noah and his sons.
4. What do you learn about sin and its influence from Noah and his sons?
5. What are you challenged to imitate or avoid?
6. a. How has your life been affected by the faults and successes of others?
6. b. How are others being affected by your faults and successes?

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read Genesis 9:24-29.
Noah prophesied about his sons' future nations. (Note: God's "curse" means He foretells of justly deserved destruction for rejecting Him and His ways. The godless Canaanite nations ended in judgment when Israel and
others conquered them.)

questions.questionText: 7. What was Noah's prophecy regarding the nations to come from the lines of his three sons?
8. What is a truth Noah's sons learned about God in this moment? At what point in your life did you learn this truth?
9. Genesis 9:29 records Noah's death. How does God's involvement in his life and Noah's legacy impact you?

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read Genesis 10.
Nations descended from Noah's sons spread out over the earth. (Note: Genesis 9 and 10 show the origin of the world's nations. Genesis 11 shows why and how they were scattered.)

questions.questionText: 10. a. Which names or places listed interest you or remind you of their mention in other Bible stories?
10. b. What does this list tell about the nations' relationship with and connection to the God of the Bible?
11. What qualities of Nimrod are highly celebrated in today's cultures? What do the cities associated with Nimrod tell you about how he used his power? (Use any cross-references or other references.)

12. What are you growing to appreciate in both the commonalities and differences among the nations represented by your family, those around you and in the world? (See Acts 17:26-27 and Revelation 7:9.)

five.title:
FIFTH DAY: Read Genesis 11:1-9.
The Lord confused the language of tower builders to scatter them.

questions.questionText: 13. How was the tower of Babel contrary to God's plan for people?
14. a. What was at the root of their desires?
14. b. How or where do these roots show up in your life?
15. What do you learn about God from how He responds to the people and their plans? (See Psalm 2:1-5.)
16. What will you pray in response to this passage and its impact on communication and unity today?
17. What have you learned about God's sovereignty and humanity's free will in this week's study?
18. Homiletics for group and administrative leaders: Genesis 9:18-11:9

LESSON/2020_8?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "The Lord had said to Abram, 'Go from your country, your people and your father's household to the land I will show you. I will make you into a great nation, and I will bless you.' " – Genesis 12:1-2a

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. What from last week's verses, lecture, notes or group sharing do you want to continue to remember and apply?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read Genesis 11:10-32.
Family information from Shem to Abram was recorded.

questions.questionText: 3. List the repeated phrases in 11:10-26. What do they teach you about Shem's line?
4. Who or what in verses 10-26 prompts your curiosity to know more?
5. Terah's descendants are featured in the rest of Genesis. What facts about Terah's family are similar to your family (11:27-32)?

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read Genesis 12:1-3.
God called Abram. Note: God later renamed Abram and Sarai to Abraham and Sarah (Genesis 17:5, 15).

questions.questionText: 6. a. Compare God's call and command to Abram with His promises.
6. b. What does Acts 7:2-4 reveal about the place and timing?
7. What else does God's Word say about His call to live by faith in Him? (Share from Isaiah 41:8-10; Matthew 4:18-22; 19:28-30; Mark 8:34-36; John 14:15-20 or other verses you may know.)
8. a. What might God be calling you to do, leave or offer to Him?
8. b. How do God's presence and promises strengthen you to answer His call?

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read Genesis 12:4-9.
Abram moved into Canaan.

questions.questionText: 9. What do you notice about Abram's obedience to God? (See Hebrews 11:1-2, 8-10.)
10.a. How do Abram's actions demonstrate his faith in God?
10.. b. What promises are you waiting on God to fulfill? How do you demonstrate your faith while waiting?

five.title:
FIFTH DAY: Read Genesis 12:10-20.
Abram and Sarai went to Egypt.

questions.questionText: 11. a. What decisions did Abram and Sarai make regarding Egypt, and why?
11. b. What truths about God and His promises are easy to forget when you're stressed or afraid?
12. What do you learn about God in this passage? What do you learn about following God?
13. How might your current stressful situation be an opportunity to positively influence how those around you view God?
14. How would you explain new life through faith in God from this week's lesson?
15. Homiletics for group and administrative leaders: Genesis 11:10-12:20

LESSON/2020_9?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "Go, walk through the length and breadth of the land, for I am giving it to you." – Genesis 13:17

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. What from last week's verses, lecture, notes or discussion most challenged or encouraged you?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read Genesis 13:1-13.
Abram and Lot separate.

questions.questionText: 3. What are some causes given for the need of Abram and Lot to separate?
4. What does the way Abram and Lot separate say about each man's character?
5. What can believers give up to put others first and to pursue peace? (See Romans 14:19-21; 1 Corinthians 6:1-7; 9:19-23 and Ephesians 4:1-3 for examples.)
6. Why is it hard to pursue peace in your relationships? How has God helped you with this?

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read Genesis 13:14-18.
God confirmed His promise to Abram.

questions.questionText: 7. What emotional and physical losses did Abram experience because of his choice?
8. What do God's responses to Abram reaffirm about His character?
9. List promises in God's Word to Christians who generously give up much for Christ's sake? (Share from Matthew 19:29-30; Romans 8:16-18 or other verses.)
10. a. How did Abram respond in faith?
10. b. What would it look like for you to respond in faith to God today?

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read Genesis 14:1-16.
Abram rescued Lot from captivity. Note: The history in 14:1-9 tells us that at least 14 years passed between Lot's move east and his capture in Sodom.

questions.questionText: 11. What was the kings' conflict, and how did they try to resolve their dispute?
12. How do you see grace at work through Abram in 14:14-16?
13. a. Compare Abram to the king of Sodom in leadership qualities.
13. b. What qualities define the kind of leader you are willing to follow or want to become?

five.title:
FIFTH DAY: Read Genesis 14:17-24.
Abram met with Melchizedek and Sodom's king.

questions.questionText: 14. What differences stand out about Abram's dealings with the king of Salem and the king of Sodom?
15. What are ways the Bible later says Melchizedek prefigured the person and work of Jesus Christ? (See Isaiah 2:3; 9:6-7; Psalm 110:4; Hebrews 2:17-18; 4:14-5:10; 6:18-7:28.)
16. a. Which of God's qualities and deeds did Melchizedek publicly proclaim in blessing Abram?
16. b. Whom can you thank for offering God's grace and blessing to you? How will you thank God for them?
17. How might this lesson affect the way you respond in your daily opportunities to trust God?
18. Homiletics for group and administrative leaders: Genesis 13-14

LESSON/2020_10?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "Abram believed the Lord, and he credited it to him as righteousness." – Genesis 15:6

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. What from the week's Bible verses, lecture, notes or discussion has helped you in daily circumstances?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read Genesis 15:1-6.
God reaffirmed his promise to give Abram descendants.

questions.questionText: 3. What do you know about shields and rewards that helps you understand God's promises in 15:1?
4. How did God's promise to be Abram's shield and great reward address Abram's fears?
5. a. What did Abram believe in 15:6?
5. b. What was the connection between belief and righteousness for Abram? What about today? (Use any Scripture references.)
6. How does God's interaction with Abram encourage, comfort or challenge you?

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read Genesis 15:7-21.
God confirmed His promises with a covenant. Note: Genesis 15:9-10, 17 describe the ceremonial rites that sealed a covenant.

questions.questionText: 7. What truths about God's character and Abram's faith are revealed?
8. List prophetic promises in 15:13-16 and say how each was fulfilled. (Use Genesis 25:7-8; Exodus 6:11; 12:31-40; and any other references.)
9. How do you reconcile God's affirmation of Abram's belief (15:6) with Abram's continued questions?
10. What means does God use to reassure His people of His promises today? (See 2 Corinthians 1:22; 5:5; Ephesians 1:13-14; and other Scriptures for your answers.)

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read Genesis 16:1-6.
Abram and Sarai sinned and conceived a child through Hagar. Note: Society in Abram's time accepted polygamy, but God ordains marriage for one man and one woman. Therefore, polygamy is outside of God's will and is sin. (See Genesis 2:24.)

questions.questionText: 11. a. How did Sarai and Abram show some faith and some unbelief in God's promise of Genesis 15:4-5?
11. b. What do you learn about the relationship between what we believe and how we behave?
12. a. What sins did Abram and Sarai commit in these verses? (Share Scripture references to support your answers.)
12. b. What were the immediate and long-term results of trying to gain something good through sin? (See also Genesis 12:10-20.)
13. What have you learned in this passage or by personal experience about waiting for God to fulfill His promises in His perfect way and time?

five.title:
FIFTH DAY: Read Genesis 16:7-16.
The angel of the Lord affirmed blessings for Hagar and Ishmael.

questions.questionText: 14. Describe Hagar's natural expectations for remaining in Sarai's charge or for running away.
15. a. What promises did the angel of the Lord make to Hagar, and who did she believe the angel of the Lord to be?
15. b. What do you learn about God through His care for Hagar and Ishmael?
16. How has God provided unimaginable good to you through a seemingly impossible situation?
17. What have you learned about how God provides for His people that encourages your faith?
18. Homiletics for group and administrative leaders: Genesis 15-16

LESSON/2020_11?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "I will establish my covenant as an everlasting covenant between me and you and your descendants after you for the generations to come, to be your God and the God of your descendants after you." – Genesis 17:7

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. What is still unclear to you or continues to encourage you from the previous lesson?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read Genesis 17:1-8.
God appeared before Abraham to confirm His covenant.

questions.questionText: 3. What do the details of the Lord's appearance to Abraham and Abraham's response tell about their relationship?
4. a. What does it mean to "be blameless" (17:1)? (Use a Bible dictionary for help.)
4. b. How could anyone accomplish God's command to be blameless? (See Matthew 5:43-48; Philippians 2:13; 3:12, 15; Colossians 1:26-29 for insights.)
5. In verses 4-8, what does God promise to do that confirms His power to carry out His will?
6. What promises in the Bible apply to you, and do you trust God to keep them? Why or why not? (Share the verses to help your group learn more about God.)

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read Genesis 17:9-14; 23-27.
God commanded circumcision, and Abraham obeyed. Note: Circumcision is a physical sign of the old covenant. Circumcision is also a spiritual sign that sin is cut off so "the circumcised" can live a life of purity and integrity.

questions.questionText: 7. How did God relate the sign of circumcision to His covenant?
8. What does Abraham's response in verses 23-27 suggest about him and his household?
9. What does Abraham show us about the right relationship between faith and works? (See Hebrews 11:8-12.)

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read Genesis 17:15-22.
God promised Sarah she would bear Isaac within the year.

questions.questionText: 10. What similar words does God repeat about Sarah in this passage and about Abraham in 17:5-8?
11. a. How do God's words show He wanted to prevent Abraham and Sarah from misinterpreting His meaning?
11. b. How does God distinguish between Isaac and Ishmael that prevents misunderstanding His will?
12. What steps do you take to avoid misinterpreting God's Word or misunderstanding His will?
13. Why might the phrase "by this time next year" have changed things for Abraham and Sarah?

five.title:
FIFTH DAY: Read Genesis 18:1-15.
The Lord appeared and reaffirmed His promise of Isaac's birth.

questions.questionText: 14. a. How might Abraham and Sarah's hospitality have differed in verses 1-8 if they were not sincerely grateful to serve?
14. b. What differences do you experience when you "have to" serve instead of when you "get to" serve?
15. How do the visitors' actions in verses 9-15 show the purpose for their arrival?
16. After she had laughed, how did Sarah know it was the Lord who had spoken?
17. What did Sarah have to believe? How is this the same for every believer today? (See Luke 1:45; Hebrews 11:6, 11.)
18. How did this week's verses impact your thinking about trusting God's promises in what seems impossible?
19. Homiletics for group and administrative leaders: Genesis 17:1-18:15

LESSON/2020_12?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "So when God destroyed the cities of the plain, he remembered Abraham, and he brought Lot out of the catastrophe that overthrew the cities where Lot had lived." – Genesis 19:29

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. What questions do you have about God's plan for the world?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read Genesis 18:16-33.
Abraham interceded with God for Sodom and Gomorrah.

6. What do you want to tell others about God's work in your life during the study of Acts and Letters of the Apostles? Who might need that encouragement to trust Jesus at this time?

LESSON/2018_1?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "There is no one holy like the Lord; there is no one besides you; there is no Rock like our God." – 1 Samuel 2:2

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. What impacted you the most from the notes or lecture?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Joshua 1:1-18.

questions.questionText: 3. What personal commission and promises did God give to Joshua? Which promise means the most to you?
4. a. What are some significant attributes of God's commands to Joshua?
4. b. What action did Joshua take after receiving them, and how might you apply these actions to your life?
5. How did Joshua handle the two and a half tribes (Reuben, Gad, Manasseh) who had settled on the eastern side of the Jordan? How would their response have encouraged him?

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Joshua 2:1-24.

questions.questionText: 6. a. How did Joshua get information about Jericho?
6. b. How might Rahab have come to strong faith in God? What are the ways Rahab expressed her faith? (See also Hebrews 11:31 and James 2:18, 22, 25.)
7. What have you learned or experienced of God that gives you boldness to trust Him in a new or risky situation you face now?
8. How did God show favor to Rahab for trusting Him? (See Joshua 6:17-25 and Matthew 1:5-6.) How has He shown you favor as you have trusted in Him?

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Joshua 3:1-4:24.

questions.questionText: 9. a. What details stand out about the preparation for crossing the Jordan?
9. b. What had Joshua told the people God would do? How did the crossing itself prove him right?
10. What was the ark? Why would it be significant that the priests carried it ahead of the people? (See Exodus 25:10-22; Hebrews 9:3-5.)

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Joshua 5:1-12.

questions.questionText: 11. What did God command Joshua to do, and why? (See Genesis 17:10-14; Exodus 12:48; Deuteronomy 30:6.)
12. a. What did the people celebrate after they healed? Why would this be meaningful? (See Numbers 9:1-5.)
12. b. What else signified the end of their desert experience, and what hope would this give?
13. Where has God made a new way for you and given hope for new provision and fruitfulness? How will you thank Him for this?
14. How did this week's study impact your thinking about God? How will that affect the actions you take in regard to a specific call of service, relationship, commitment or leadership position?

LESSON/2018_2?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "Have I not commanded you? Be strong and courageous. Do not be afraid; do not be discouraged, for the Lord your God will be with you wherever you go." – Joshua 1:9

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. What from the notes, lecture, group sharing or personal study impacted you most in the past week?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Joshua 5:13-6:27.

questions.questionText: 3. Who did Joshua meet near Jericho? Why might he have replied to Joshua's questions as he did?
4. a. How would the Lord's words have encouraged Joshua, considering the walls of Jericho were tightly shut? What do they tell us about God?
4. b. What was unique or interesting about the battle strategy? What effect might it have had on the Israelites and the residents of Jericho?
5. a. What did God command the Israelites to do to Jericho, and why? Whom were they to spare, and why? (For help, see Genesis 15:16; Deuteronomy 12:29-32; Deuteronomy 20:16-18; Leviticus 18:24-28.)
5. b. Describe any struggle you may have to reconcile God's wrath against sin and His love for people.

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Joshua 7.

questions.questionText: 6. What was Joshua's response to the battle of Ai? What does his prayer reveal about his knowledge of and relationship with God?
7. What did God reveal to Joshua? How did Achan respond when caught, and what resulted?
8. What consequences have you experienced because of wrongdoing (yours or others')?

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Joshua 8.

questions.questionText: 9. a. What do you learn about God from His words to Joshua before the battle?
9. b. How did God's battle plan differ from the spies' plan in 7:3?
10. Why did Joshua read God's words to the entire assembly after the battle at Ai? (See Deuteronomy 11:26-30 and 27:2-8 for Moses' instructions.)
11. How can you share a love for and commitment to God's Word with your family and those around you?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Joshua 9.

questions.questionText: 12. How did the surrounding nations respond to the Israelites' victories? What did this prompt the Gibeonites to do?
13. What should Joshua have done in response to the Gibeonites' request? Why did Joshua keep his promise to the Gibeonites? (See Exodus 34:12, 15; Numbers 30:2; Deuteronomy 7:2.)
14. Through this week's lesson, how is God moving you to engage with the world, share a truth or show His love and kindness?

LESSON/2018_3?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "The commander of the Lord's army replied, 'Take off your sandals, for the place where you are standing is holy.' And Joshua did so." – Joshua 5:15

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. What from the notes, lecture, group sharing or personal study impacted you most in the past week?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Joshua 10:1-15.

questions.questionText: 3. How did Joshua respond to the new challenge he faced? How did God encourage him?
4. What did God do supernaturally for Joshua and the Israelite army? What do these verses reveal about God?
5. What principles about integrity and prayer can you draw from these verses?

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Joshua 10:16-43.

questions.questionText: 6. What was the reaction of the surrounding Canaanites after Joshua's armies returned from routing the armies of the five cities? What was the reason for it?

7. What did Joshua tell his men to do when they brought the five kings to him? What does this total victory point toward? (For help, see Psalm 110:1; Romans 16:20; 1 Corinthians 15:24-27 and any other Bible passages.)
8. How does the reality that God fights for His people encourage you as you fight against discouragement, temptation, worry, etc.?

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Joshua 11.

questions.questionText: 9. What command and promise did the Lord give Joshua as a large number of kings joined forces to fight Israel? What does it tell you about Joshua, his enemies and God?
10. What was the significance of the destruction of the Anakites? (See Numbers 13:21-14:9; Deuteronomy 9:1-5 for help.)
11. What questions or doubts have you struggled with as you read these chapters describing violence and destruction?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Joshua 12.

questions.questionText: 12. Why would God include this list of defeated kings in the Bible? What does this chapter reveal about God's word, character and promises? (See Genesis 15:18-19; Exodus 23:31-33)
13. What inspires you about Joshua?
14. What habits or practices in your life will you ask God to help you conquer?

15. Choose one or more verses from this week's lesson, and quietly think deeply (meditate) on what is written. Are you taking these verses to heart and living them? Share with your group what God has revealed to you.

LESSON/2018_4?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "All these kings and their lands Joshua conquered in one campaign, because the Lord, the God of Israel, fought for Israel." – Joshua 10:42

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. What from the notes, lecture, group sharing or personal study impacted you most in the past week?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Skim Joshua 13-14.
Joshua 13-19 explain the division of the land among the tribes. Recurring themes include God faithfulness, His plans for each generation and the boundaries He sets.

questions.questionText: 3. What does the allotment of land reveal about Moses, the Israelites and God?
4. How does Caleb's story and request inspire you? (Read 14:6-14. Caleb's story is also recorded in Numbers 13:26-14:10, 20-24, 30, 36-38.)
5. How has God demonstrated His faithfulness as you have persevered through difficult seasons?

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Skim Joshua 15-19.
In the details about land boundaries, look for how God keeps His promises to all without overlooking individuals or the need to prepare the next generation.

questions.questionText: 6. Why would God include these long, detailed lists of land boundaries and allotments in the Bible?
7. What do you learn about God's heart for women from Caleb's daughter and Zelophehad's daughters? (See Joshua 15:13-19; Joshua 17:3-6.)

8. How does Caleb's attitude and approach towards taking the land differ from the Manassites'? How does this encourage or challenge you? (See Joshua 14:6-15; Joshua 15:13-19; Joshua 17:7-18 for help.)

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read Joshua 20 with Numbers 35:6-34.
Joshua 20-21 describe the inheritance of the tribe of Levi, which served as priests for Israel. Joshua 20 especially highlights God's concern for justice and human life.

questions.questionText: 9. Describe the purpose and intent of the cities of refuge.
10. What do the cities of refuge reveal about God and His people?
11. What do you learn about God in His provision of the cities of refuge that challenges, convicts or comforts you?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Skim Joshua 21.

questions.questionText: 12. What was the role of the Levites? Why did they receive cities instead of an inheritance of land? (See Numbers 18 for help.)
13. Why would it be beneficial to have the Levites spread out among all the tribes?

14. How does the New Testament describe the inheritance of believers? What "deposit" does God give believers as a guarantee? (See 1 Peter 1:3-5; Ephesians 1:13-14; 1 Corinthians 15:50-56 and any other Bible passages.)
15. What does Joshua 21:43-45 reveal about God? How do these truths reassure you in your present situation?
16. What did you learn about God, and what did you learn about yourself this week?

LESSON/2018_5?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "Not one of all the Lord's good promises to Israel failed; every one was fulfilled." – Joshua 21:45

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. What from the notes, lecture, group sharing or personal study impacted you most in the past week?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read Joshua 22.
Joshua 22 gives the account of the tribes of Reuben, Gad and half-tribe of Manasseh returning to their land east of
the Jordan River. The separation caused by the river caused some difficulties and fears for the 12 tribes.

questions.questionText: 3. How did Joshua commend and challenge the eastern tribes? (See Joshua 22:1-8.)
4. What did the western tribes fear after the eastern tribes built the altar? How did the eastern tribes defend their motives in building the altar? (For help, see Deuteronomy 12:10-14.)
5. What does this encounter teach you about dealing with confrontation in a God-honoring manner?

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read Joshua 23.
Joshua 23 warns the Israelite leaders to remain devoted and obedient to the Lord.

questions.questionText: 6. What did Joshua want the Israelites to recognize and remember about God?
7. What truths about God can we learn from all He did for Israel?
8. How did Joshua instruct Israel? What was the danger for Israel should they choose to disobey?
9. Why would Joshua address the leaders separately? What does this teach you about the need for and value of godly leadership?

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read Joshua 24:1-13.
Joshua 24 records Joshua's final reminders and warnings to the nation of Israel.

questions.questionText: 10. What stands out to you in reading Israel's history, and why?
11. What does the retelling of Israel's history reveal about God?
12. Why is it important to read, tell and hear stories of God's past faithfulness? How do you or could you put that into practice?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Joshua 24:14-33.

questions.questionText: 13. What choice did Joshua present to the nation? How do we make choices everyday about whom we will serve?
14. Why do you think Joshua did not readily accept their pledge to serve the Lord in verse 18? What lessons do you learn from Joshua's example?
15. What did Joshua mean by God's jealousy in 24:19? What examples can you think of where jealousy is an appropriate response? (See 2 Corinthians 11:2-4.)
16. What would you like to see God do in your heart or in your life this week?

LESSON/2018_6?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "But you are to hold fast to the Lord your God, as you have until now." – Joshua 23:8

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. What from the notes, lecture, group sharing or personal study impacted you most in the past week?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read Ruth 1.
Ruth 1 explains why Elimelek moved his family to Moab and the events prior to Naomi's return to Israel.

questions.questionText: 3. Describe Israel's relationship with Moab. What happened to Elimelek's family in Moab? (See Numbers 25:1-3; Deuteronomy 23:3-6.)
4. What did Ruth potentially give up by going with Naomi? What did Ruth think she might gain by going with Naomi?
5. In what way has suffering and misfortune affected your attitude, family or decisions? How has your view of God been impacted by these situations?

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read Ruth 2.
Ruth gleaned in Boaz's field because God's law allowed the poor to glean the leftovers so they could eat.

questions.questionText: 6. Who was Boaz, and what character traits did he display? Why did he help Ruth, the Moabite? (See Matthew 1:5.)
7. What does Scripture tell us about Boaz's potential responsibility as a near relative (guardian-redeemer) of Elimelek? (See Leviticus 25:23-25; Deuteronomy 25:5-6.)
8. How does this passage impact your heart toward the marginalized (poor, refugee, homeless, etc.)?

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read Ruth 3.
Ruth 3 relates Naomi's plan for Ruth and Boaz.

questions.questionText: 9. Why did Naomi resort to this plan? What were the potential pros and cons of the plan?
10. The Hebrew word translated "garment" in Ruth 3:9 is the same Hebrew word translated as "wings" in Ruth 2:12. What was Ruth saying to Boaz in her actions? Why would she say it in that way?
11. Give similarities and differences in how Boaz treated Ruth and how Jesus Christ treats those who come to Him. (You may use any additional Scripture references.)

five.title:
FIFTH DAY: Read Ruth 4.
Ruth 4 gives perspective into ways God works through suffering for good.

questions.questionText: 12. What does "redeem" mean? Describe all the ways you see God's redemptive work in this chapter.
13. What do you know about David? Why would Scripture twice emphasize Obed's relationship to David? (See 2 Samuel 7:5-29, Matthew 1:1 or any other scripture reference.)
14. How does this story give you hope as you wait on the Lord in your present circumstances?
15. What have you learned about God and Jesus your Redeemer in this week's study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?
16. Homiletics for group and administrative leaders: Ruth 1-4

LESSON/2018_7?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “The women said to Naomi: ‘Praise be to the LORD, who this day has not left you without a guardian-redeemer. May he become famous throughout Israel!’ ” – Ruth 4:14

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God’s activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. What from the notes, lecture, group sharing or personal study impacted you most in the past week?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read 1 Samuel 1.
Chapter 1 focuses on God’s gracious response to an Israelite woman enduring great disappointment.

questions.questionText: 3. What was Hannah’s situation at home, and how did she handle it?
4. What lessons can you learn from Eli’s interaction with Hannah? How might you apply those lessons in your life?
5. How does Hannah’s response reveal her faith and love for God? What challenges you personally from Hannah’s example?

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read 1 Samuel 2:1-11.
Hannah offered Samuel to the Lord and responded with rejoicing and prayer.

questions.questionText: 6. What do you learn about God’s character and work from Hannah’s prayer? How does this help you in your present circumstances?
7. Who else in Scripture was willing to sacrifice their son for God’s glory? What are you willing to sacrifice in order to bring glory to God? (Use any scripture reference.)
8. What does Hannah’s prayer reveal about God’s future plans?

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read 1 Samuel 2:12-36.
Chapters 2-3 reveal a contrast between Eli’s family and Samuel.

questions.questionText: 9. Describe the sins of Eli’s sons and Eli’s response to their sin. (See also Leviticus 7:28-36.)
10. What did God promise would happen to Eli’s family because of their unwillingness to repent?
11. What behaviors (of yours or of others close to you) are you tempted to ignore or enable? How is God inviting you to respond?

five.title:
FIFTH DAY: Read 1 Samuel 3.
God spoke and revealed His plans through Samuel.

questions.questionText: 12. What stands out to you about God’s interactions with Samuel and Samuel’s interactions with Eli?
13. What does this chapter reveal about the privilege and the responsibility of being the Lord’s servant?
14. What has God revealed to you in His Word? How can you make known God’s Word to others?
15. What attribute of God resonated most from your study of this week’s passage? How do you see that attribute displayed in the world today?

LESSON/2018_8?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "The Lord came and stood there, calling as at the other times, 'Samuel, Samuel!' Then Samuel said, 'Speak, for your servant is listening.' " – 1 Samuel 3:10

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. What from the notes, lecture, group sharing or personal study impacted you most in the past week?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read 1 Samuel 4-5.
God revealed His power over the Philistine gods.

questions.questionText: 3. What was the ark of the covenant? What did the Israelites hope to accomplish by taking it into battle? (See Exodus 25:10-22; Numbers 7:89; 1 Samuel 4:22; Hebrews 9:1-4.)
4. Trace the effects of the ark's presence in these chapters. What lessons do you learn about God?
5. How are Christians guilty of trying to use God or His Word to get what they want today?

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read 1 Samuel 6.
God revealed His power and holiness to the Philistines and Israelites as the ark was returned to Israel.

questions.questionText: 6. How did the Philistines combine their knowledge and fear of God with superstition? Give examples of how believers and unbelievers do this today.
7. What happened once the ark was returned to Beth Shemesh (Israel)? How do believers trample on God's holiness today? (See Numbers 4:5-6, 20.)
8. What do you learn about God's character in this passage? How does that encourage you in your present circumstances?

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read 1 Samuel 7.
Samuel led and interceded for Israel.

questions.questionText: 9. How did Samuel demonstrate godly leadership? Which examples will you implement with your family, children or others you lead?
10. How did the Israelites demonstrate faith and true repentance? What were the results?
11. Compare and contrast the battles in chapters 4 and 7. What lessons can you learn from these two battles?

five.title:
FIFTH DAY: Read 1 Samuel 8.
Samuel warned the Israelites of the consequences for insisting on an earthly king.

questions.questionText: 12. Why did the Israelites ask for a king? What did Samuel say would be the cost of having a king?
13. What do you learn about God or people in this passage?
14. How do believers try to be like the world today? At what cost?
15. How did this week's study impact your thinking about repentance, grace, faith or obedience?

LESSON/2018_9?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “Then Samuel took a stone and set it up between Mizpah and Shen. He named it Ebenezer, saying, ‘Thus far the LORD has helped us.’ ” – 1 Samuel 7:12

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God’s activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. What from the notes, lecture, group sharing or personal study impacted you most in the past week?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read 1 Samuel 9-10.
God directed Samuel to anoint and instruct Saul as Israel’s first king.

questions.questionText: 3. How did God reveal Saul was His choice for Israel’s first king?
4. What signs and instructions did Samuel give Saul?  What does this reveal about the king’s relationship to God and His prophets?
5. What do you learn about God’s call to a specific work? What is the work God has for you?

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read 1 Samuel 11.
God granted Saul and the Israelites victory over the Ammonites.

questions.questionText: 6. What difficult situation did the people face? What seemingly impossible situation are you facing or have faced in the past?
7. What changes were evident in Saul when the Holy Spirit came upon him? (1 Samuel 10:22-26)
8. How has the Holy Spirit’s indwelling changed and empowered you?

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read 1 Samuel 12-13.
Samuel instructed Israel to remember the Lord, but Saul ignored his instructions.

questions.questionText: 9. In Samuel’s farewell speech, what did he say about himself, God and the people?
10. How did the people respond? How did Samuel instruct and encourage them?
11. Why did Saul disobey Samuel’s instructions? What were the consequences for Saul’s disobedience? (1 Samuel 10:8)
12. What pressures to disobey do you face? How have you been impacted by your own or other’s disobedience to God?

five.title:
FIFTH DAY: Read 1 Samuel 14-15.
Saul demonstrated unwise and ungodly leadership before God rejected him as king.

questions.questionText: 13. How does Jonathan’s courage and reliance on God in His battle against the Philistines inspire you? (1 Samuel 14:1-23)
14. What do the events in this battle reveal about Saul’s character and leadership?
15. How did Saul excuse his disobedience? What excuses do you or others offer for your disobedience?
16. What do you learn about God through Saul’s failures? How does this comfort or challenge you?
17. What was your biggest takeaway from your personal study of this week’s lesson?

LESSON/2018_10?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "For the sake of his great name the Lord will not reject his people, because the Lord was pleased to make you his own." – 1 Samuel 12:22

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. What from the notes, lecture, group sharing or personal study impacted you most in the past week?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read 1 Samuel 16:1-13 with 15:34-35.
God directed Samuel to anoint David as the next king of Israel.

questions.questionText: 3. How did God address Samuel's sorrow and misgivings? What lesson(s) do you learn?
4. What insights did the Lord give Samuel as he considered Jesse's sons? How do those insights challenge, warn or impact you?
5. What do you learn about the way God views people? How does this compare to what you value in yourself and others? (See also Psalm 44:21.)

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read 1 Samuel 16:14-23.
Newly anointed David began to serve King Saul.

questions.questionText: 6. What happened to Saul? What might have been some reasons it occurred? (For help, see Deuteronomy 28:15, 28; 1 Samuel 15:16-29; Lamentations 3:39.)
7. How did God move David from the shepherd's fields to serving in the palace? What characteristics are evident in David as he served Saul?
8. Where and how has God called you to use the gifts He has given you?

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read 1 Samuel 17:1-32.
David arrived at the battleground and assessed the threat.

questions.questionText: 9. What threat did Saul and the Israelite army face? How did they respond?
10. How did Goliath taunt the Israelites? What was his idea to settle the battle?
11. How did David's perspective differ from his brothers' and the other soldiers'? What do their words and actions reveal about their belief in God?
12. In your present circumstances, what do your words and actions reveal about your belief in God?

five.title:
FIFTH DAY: Read 1 Samuel 17:33-58.
The Lord saved the Israelites through David's victory.

questions.questionText: 13. How did David's prior experiences of God's power give him courage to face this challenge? How does this help or encourage you?
14. How did David's actions and words to Saul, the Israelites and Goliath express his absolute confidence in God?
15. In what specific ways could you follow David's example in your own present circumstances?
16. From this passage, what similarities are there between David and Jesus Christ? (Use any Scripture reference.)
17. What would you like to see God do in your life this week?

LESSON/2018_11?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "The Lord does not look at the things people look at. People look at the outward appearance, but the Lord looks at the heart." – 1 Samuel 16:7b

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. From the past week's study, what made the most significant impact to you in the notes, lecture, group sharing or personal study?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read Psalm 139.
Psalms compile song lyrics and prayers from many authors. This lesson focuses on the Psalms David wrote.

questions.questionText: 3. What do you learn about God's universal and personal knowledge and power?
4. How does David's longing and request reveal his zeal for God and hatred of sin? How can a Christian balance hatred of sin and love for those opposed to God today? (Psalm 139:19-24)
5. How is this Psalm relevant to your present circumstances? (Are you trying to run from Him, being honest with Him, feeling persecuted, etc.?)

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read Psalms 7 and 10.
Psalms 7 and 10 demonstrate praise and petition through suffering.

questions.questionText: 6. Which attributes of God stand out to you? Why?
7. What do these psalms reveal about those who perpetrate wickedness and those who are afflicted?
8. Who and what is David's constant hope? Who and what is your hope?

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read Psalm 19
David praised God's revelation in creation and His Word.

questions.questionText: 9. God's glory has been defined as the sum total of His attributes. What attributes of God are revealed through creation? (Use any Scripture reference.)
10. How does David describe God's Word? How is your attitude toward God's Word similar or different?
11. How does David describe the benefits of studying God's Word? What specific differences has studying God's Word made in you?

five.title:
FIFTH DAY: Read Psalms 2 and 110.
David pleaded for deliverance often and in confident, prophetic anticipation of Jesus Christ.

questions.questionText: 12. What is the complaint against God in Psalm 2:1-3? How does this compare with people's complaints against God today?
13. What is God's gracious answer to the world's rebellion? How can God justly spare all the wicked who take refuge in his Son? (See Psalm 2:4-13 and Isaiah 53:4-6.)
14. What does Psalm 110 reveal about Jesus? (For help, see Acts 2:33-36; Mark 14:61-62; Hebrews 1:13; 4:14-16; 7:11-8:2 or any other scripture references.)
15. What conviction, confidence or hope do these psalms give you today?

16. Choose one or more verses from this week's lesson, and quietly think deeply (meditate) on what is written. How is God calling you to take to heart and act on these verses? Share with your group what God has revealed to you.

LESSON/2018_12?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "All the ends of the earth will remember and turn to the Lord, and all the families of the nations will bow down before him." – Psalm 22:27

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. From the past week's study, what made the most significant impact to you in the notes, lecture, group sharing or personal study?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read 1 Samuel 18.
David experienced strained relations with Saul and strong relationships with Saul's children.

questions.questionText: 3. What is most interesting to you concerning David's relationships with Saul, Jonathan and Michal. Why?
4. What lessons or warnings do you learn from Saul? In what area of your life could you apply these lessons?
5. How does David experience both the blessing and cost of following God? How have you seen both the blessing and cost of following Jesus in your own life?

14. What were the results of Solomon's response to David's instructions? What spiritual and practical lessons do you learn about work God entrusts to people? (See 1 Kings 2:12, 46.)

six.title: SIXTH DAY: Read 1 Kings 1-2 with 1 Chronicles 22, 29.

questions.questionText: 15. How did this week's study impact the influence you desire to have on and the legacy you want to leave to others (family, church, community, etc.)?

LESSON/2018_24?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "Since my youth, God, you have taught me, and to this day I declare your marvelous deeds." – Psalm 71:17

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. What from the notes, lecture, group sharing or personal study impacted you most in the past week?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read 1 Kings 3:1-4; 2 Chronicles 1:1-6; Deuteronomy 17:16-20.
Solomon loved the Lord but sacrificed on the high places.

questions.questionText: 3. Describe Solomon's actions in view of God's instructions in Deuteronomy 17:16-20.
4. Give examples of actions you or your culture may applaud but that may trap or mislead God's people.
5. From the Deuteronomy passage, what were some of the good purposes behind God's instructions? How have God's instructions protected or blessed you?

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read 1 Kings 3:5-28; 2 Chronicles 1:7-13; Proverbs 1.
Solomon asked for and applied his God-given wisdom.

questions.questionText: 6. How did Solomon respond to God's gracious invitation? What do you learn about Solomon from his request?
7. How did God respond to Solomon's request? What do you learn about God from His answer?
8. What does Proverbs 1 teach about becoming wise? How will you apply what you are learning?

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read 1 Kings 4:1-28; 2 Chronicles 1:14-17.
Solomon established Israel's government and ruled in peace and prosperity.

questions.questionText: 9. How did Solomon show discernment in the practical ways he governed Israel? What can and will you apply in your home or workplace?
10. How did the nation of Israel benefit under Solomon's rule? (See Ecclesiastes 3:10-14; 5:18-20.)

11. What are some potential temptations and distractions that arise during times of prosperity and ease? How will you guard against those that particularly tempt or distract you? (See Deuteronomy 8:10-18; 17:16-17.)

five.title:
FIFTH DAY: Read 1 Kings 4:29-34.
Solomon's wisdom surpassed all others.

questions.questionText: 12. How do these verses show God fulfilled His promises to Solomon? (See 1 Kings 3:10-15.) How does this encourage you as you wait on God to fulfill His promises today?

13. What stands out to you about Solomon's God-given wisdom? How does Solomon's experience demonstrate the way God gives supreme wisdom? (See 1 Corinthians 1: 18-25; James 1:5; 3:13-17 or any other Scripture reference.)
14. What had Solomon learned about wisdom? In what ways have you experienced what Solomon says about wisdom? (See Ecclesiastes 1:16-18; 2:13; 4:13; 8:1.)

six.title: SIXTH DAY: Review 1 Kings 3-4; 2 Chronicles 1; and Proverbs 1.

questions.questionText: 15. How did this week's study impact your thinking about God's wisdom vs. the world's wisdom?
16. Homiletics for group and administrative leaders: 1 Kings 3-4.

LESSON/2018_25?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "The fear of the Lord is the beginning of knowledge, but fools despise wisdom and instruction." – Proverbs 1:7

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. From the past week's study, what made the most significant impact to you in the notes, lecture, group sharing or personal study?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read Proverbs 1.
Proverbs 1-9 offer advice godly parents and mentors can pass on to others.

questions.questionText: 3. Explain Proverbs 1:7 in your own words. What does it mean to "fear the Lord"?
4. What are some of the benefits of wisdom? Which one is most relevant or comforting to you?
5. Skim Proverbs 2-3 to note a few warnings and commands that stand out to you. Which one calls you to change your response to a current circumstance?

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read Proverbs 14 and 16.
Proverbs 10:1-22:16 describe growth in wise living and the costs of foolishness.

questions.questionText: 6. How does Proverbs 14 describe a wise person? Which characteristics would you like God to grow in you?
7. What does Proverbs 14 reveal about God? What truth comforts or challenges you most?
8. What truths does Proverbs 16 reveal about speech? How will you practice wise speech in your home, friendships, church and workplace?

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read Proverbs 28 and 29.
Proverbs 22:17-29:27 describe good citizenship for community and family life.

questions.questionText: 9. Which verses about leadership (rulers) will you apply? How?
10. Which verses about wealth and poverty will you put into practice? How?
11. What did you learn about righteous and wicked living? How do these verses challenge or comfort you?

five.title:
FIFTH DAY: Read Proverbs 30-31.
Proverbs 30-31 describe observing wisdom in action to learn from others.

questions.questionText: 12. From Proverbs 30, what observations about nature and life are most practical to you? Why?
13. a. Proverbs 31 personifies wisdom as "the wife of noble character." What aspects of this ideal image stand out to you?
13. b. How do these descriptions help you recognize wisdom in others and call you to become a wiser member in your family and church?
14. Which of these verses will you share with those who have been entrusted to your care?

15. Choose a few verses from this lesson and think about how the truths line up with your daily actions. Where do you see yourself living out these verses? Where do you see a need for change? Share with your group what God's Word has revealed to you. (No homiletics for group or administrative leaders)

LESSON/2018_26?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "Trust in the Lord with all your heart and lean not on your own understanding; in all your ways submit to him, and he will make your paths straight." – Proverbs 3:5-6

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. From the past week's study, what made the most significant impact to you in the notes, lecture, group sharing or personal study?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read 1 Kings 5:1-6.
Solomon asked the king of Tyre for resources to build God's temple.

questions.questionText: 3. What did Solomon plan to do as king? What opportunities did Solomon see and seize?
4. Describe how God made advance preparations before Solomon initiated building the temple. How did circumstances confirm the timing of Solomon's desire?
5. How are you, or will you, take initiative in the work God has given you? Where is God inviting you to trust Him?

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read 1 Kings 5:7-18.
Solomon assembled the resources and labor to build the temple.

questions.questionText: 6. How did Solomon use his wisdom, influence and resources to implement and accomplish this massive undertaking? What stands out in the negotiations and agreement between Solomon and Hiram? (2 Chronicles 2 provides additional details.)

7. What thoughts or questions did you have regarding Solomon's use of conscripted Israelite labor and enslavement of foreigners? (Use 1 Kings 9:20-22, 2 Chronicles 2:17-18 or any passage of Scripture.)
8. What desire or opportunity has God given you that appears to be greater than your ability? How do God's dealings with Solomon encourage you to go forward in obedience?

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read 1 Kings 6:1-13.
God gave promises to Solomon while he was building the temple.

questions.questionText: 9. What other events occurred in the Mount Moriah region? What connections do you see between these events and the temple? (See Genesis 22:1-18; 2 Samuel 24:18-25; 2 Chronicles 3:1 and any other reference in Scripture.)
10. What promises did God make to Solomon as he built the temple? Why would God give this message at this particular time?
11. How does God help you prioritize your relationship with Him during the daily work and demands of life?

five.title:
FIFTH DAY: Read 1 Kings 6:14-38.
Solomon completed the temple.

questions.questionText: 12. What were Solomon's goals in building the temple? Why? (See 2 Chronicles 2:4-9.)
13. What stands out to you in the temple construction and completion? Why?
14. How does a person work and serve in a way that reflects the greatness of God instead of the worker? How might you need to adjust your work and service to better reflect God's greatness?

six.title: SIXTH DAY: Review 1 Kings 5-6 and 2 Chronicles 2-3.

questions.questionText: 15. What was your biggest lesson learned from your personal study this week?
16. Homiletics for group and administrative leaders: 1 Kings 5-6.

LESSON/2018_27?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "And I will live among the Israelites and will not abandon my people Israel." – 1 Kings 6:13

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. From the past week's study, what made the most significant impact to you in the notes, lecture, group sharing or personal study?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read 1 Kings 7:1-51.
Solomon constructed his palace and commissioned the temple furnishings.

questions.questionText: 3. Why does Scripture mention the time Solomon spent building the temple and the palace at this point? What are some possible lessons?
4. How was Huram described? How does this affect your thinking about different ways to serve God?
5. What was the purpose of the temple vessels and furnishings in Solomon's day? To whom did they point? (Use 2 Chronicles 4; Hebrews 9:1-23; Revelation 21:22-22:5 or any other reference.)

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read 1 Kings 8:1-11.
The priests brought the ark of the covenant to the Most Holy Place.

questions.questionText: 6. What did the ark of the covenant signify? What is meaningful to you about the ark's transport and placement? (Use Exodus 25:22; 1 Samuel 4:21-22; 6:1-21 or any other reference.)
7. How does God dwell among people today? How can you be sure God dwells in you? (Use John 10:29; 2 Corinthians 6:16 or any other reference.)

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read 1 Kings 8:11-21.
The dark cloud filled God's temple.

questions.questionText: 8. Who and what did the dark cloud that filled the temple represent? (See Exodus 24:15-18; 33:7-11.)
9. Where and how is the Lord's glory seen since the days of Jesus Christ? (See Psalm 19; Acts 2; 2 Corinthians 3:17-18 or any other reference.)
10. What opportunities is God giving you to reflect His character?
11. Solomon celebrated and told others of God's faithfulness to keep His promises. How will you do the same thing?

five.title:
FIFTH DAY: Read 1 Kings 8:22-66.
Solomon prayed and dedicated the temple.

questions.questionText: 12. What did Solomon's prayer reveal about his understanding of and belief about God?
13. What did Solomon's prayer reveal about his understanding of and belief about the nation of Israel, and all mankind?
14. How might Solomon's prayer affect the way you pray? What will you put into practice?
15. What did you learn about God? What did you learn about yourself?
16. Homiletics for group and administrative leaders: 1 Kings 7-8.

LESSON/2018_28?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "Lord, the God of Israel, there is no God like you in heaven above or on earth below--you who keep your covenant of love with your servants who continue wholeheartedly in your way." – 1 Kings 8:23

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. From the past week's study, what made the most significant impact to you in the notes, lecture, group sharing or personal study?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read 1 Kings 9:1-9.
The Lord appeared to Solomon a second time.

questions.questionText: 3. What had Solomon accomplished at the point the Lord appeared to him a second time? (1 Kings 4:24-34)
4. What warnings and promises did God make to Solomon? What was the point of these words?
5. What does it look like to "walk faithfully with integrity of heart and uprightness"? How is this reminder relevant in your current circumstances?

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read 1 Kings 9:10-28; 2 Chronicles 8.
Solomon built his kingdom.

questions.questionText: 6. What was the focus of Solomon's time and energy during these years?
7. How did Solomon demonstrate both wisdom and questionable judgment?
8. What does the way you spend your time and energy say about you? How do you measure the success of a pursuit?

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read 1 Kings 10:1-13.
The Queen of Sheba visited Solomon.

questions.questionText: 9. What drew the Queen of Sheba to Solomon? Once she met him, what impressed the Queen of Sheba about Solomon?
10. What conclusion did the Queen of Sheba make about having a ruler who applies godly wisdom? What conclusion did she make about God?

11. Compare the similarities and differences between King Solomon and King Jesus. Perhaps you are wondering if Jesus is all that He claims to be. What hard questions would you like to ask Jesus? (Use any reference in Scripture.)

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read 1 Kings 10:14-29; Psalm 72.

questions.questionText: 12. Psalm 72 is a prayer of David for his son Solomon. How was this prayer answered through Solomon's life? For whom does this encourage you to pray?
13. What does Solomon's experience reveal about the blessings and challenges of great wealth and talent? What is the lesson for you?
14. What is the most important or challenging thing you learned this week?
15. Homiletics for group and administrative leaders: 1 Kings 9-10.

LESSON/2018_29?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "Because of the Lord's eternal love for Israel, he has made you king to maintain justice and righteousness." – 1 Kings 10:9b

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. From the past week's study, what made the most significant impact to you in the notes, lecture, group sharing or personal study?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read 1 Kings 11:1-8.
Solomon loved forbidden women and worshipped false gods.

questions.questionText: 3. What commands did Solomon disobey? (See Exodus 34:11-17; Deuteronomy 17:16-17 or any other Scripture reference.)
4. Why does God set boundaries around marriage? How are God's boundaries for marriage for the good of His children, then and now?
5. How do you proceed when God's commands come into conflict with your decisions and desires?

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read 1 Kings 11:9-13.
God promised to divide the kingdom because of Solomon's disobedience.

questions.questionText: 6. Why was God angry with Solomon? Why does God command our undivided worship? (Use Psalm 16:11; Ecclesiastes 2:1-10; Isaiah 45:5-6; 46:3-10; Acts 17:25 or any Scripture reference.)
7. Solomon attempted to worship God and idols. What are some present-day examples of idolatry? What in your life might be an idol?
8. What consequences did God promise would come to Solomon and his kingdom? What do you learn about God's timing, justice and mercy?

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read 1 Kings 11:14-26.
God raised up adversaries against Solomon.

questions.questionText: 9. Describe the adversaries God "raised up" against Solomon. How did God demonstrate faithfulness to His promises? (See 1 Kings 6:12; 9:3-9)
10. What are the opposing forces God's people face today? (For help, see John 15:18-21; Ephesians 6:12; 1 Peter 5:8; James 1:13-14; 1 John 2:16.)
11. What is your first response when hardship and adversaries arise? How has God used opposition and hardship to turn your heart and attention back to Him?

five.title:
FIFTH DAY: Read 1 Kings 11:26-43; Ecclesiastes 9:12; 12:1-14.
Jeroboam learned God's intent to give him 10 tribes.

questions.questionText: 12. What did the Lord promise Jeroboam? What were the conditions?
13. What can you infer about Solomon's last months of life? Why did he summarize life as he did? (See Ecclesiastes 9:12; 12:1-14.)
14. As you reflect back over Solomon's life, what lessons do you want to remember? How will they shape the way you live?
15. What attribute of God resonated most from your study of this week's passage? How do you see that attribute displayed in the world today?
16. Homiletics for group and administrative leaders: 1 Kings 11.

LESSON/2018_30?lang=eng.memoryVerse: "Many are the plans in a person's heart, but it is the Lord's purpose that prevails." – Proverbs 19:21

one.title: FIRST DAY:

questions.questionText: 1. What did you learn about God through the study of People of the Promised Land I, and what difference has that made in your life?

two.title: SECOND DAY:

questions.questionText: 2. What did you learn about yourself during the study, and how did God use that to draw you closer to Him?

three.title: THIRD DAY:

questions.questionText: 3. In what ways did you experience God changing your thoughts, attitudes, desires and actions this year? How did you see Him work in the lives of the children you bring to BSF?

four.title: FOURTH DAY:

questions.questionText: 4. How has your relationship with Jesus Christ changed this year, and what impact has that had on your relationships with others?

five.title: FIFTH DAY:

questions.questionText: 5. Now that you have completed the study of People of the Promised Land I, what do you think God's plan for you includes?
6. What do you want to tell others about God's work in your life during the study of People of the Promised Land I? Who might need that encouragement to trust Jesus at this time?

LESSON/2017_1?lang=eng.name: Romans2017_1
LESSON/2017_1?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “For I am not ashamed of the gospel, because it is the power of God that brings salvation to everyone who believes: first to the Jew, then to the Gentile.” – Romans 1:16

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 1:1-7.

questions.questionText: 3. What do you learn about Paul from his introduction? (See also Acts 9:1-21; 1 Timothy 1:12-16.)
4. The word “gospel” means “good news.” What news do these verses announce, why is it good, and how have you experienced this goodness?
5. How did Paul describe the Roman Christians, what did he offer them, and how do his words affect your attitude about yourself or other believers?

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 1:8-10.

questions.questionText: 6. Whom did Paul thank, and why was he grateful?
7. What do you learn about the relationship between serving God and prayer?
8. a.  For what specifically did Paul pray, and how did God answer Paul’s prayer? (See Acts 28:14-20,30-31.)
8. b. What do you learn about God from Paul’s prayers, and for whom or for what does this encourage you to pray?

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 1:11-15.

questions.questionText: 9. Why did Paul want to come to the Roman church, and why had he not come previously?
10.  How could Paul’s example help you when you face obstacles in serving God?
