11. Why was Paul obligated to all people, and what was his attitude toward his obligation? What is your attitude toward your obligation to share your knowledge of Jesus with others? (See also Acts 26:11-18.)

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 1:16-17. Note: These verses are the theme of the entire book of Romans.

questions.questionText: 12. List reasons Paul was not ashamed of the gospel.
13. In what situations are you tempted to be ashamed of the gospel, and how could Paul’s reasons help you?
14. How do these verses relate to your personal experience of the gospel, and how are they also Paul’s personal  testimony? (See Philippians 3:4-9.)
15.  What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?

LESSON/2017_2?lang=eng.name: Romans2017_2
LESSON/2017_2?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “For in the gospel the righteousness of God is revealed – a righteousness that is by faith from first to last, just as it is written: ‘The righteous will live by faith.’ ” – Romans 1:17

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 1:18-20.

questions.questionText: 3.  Define the word “wrath,” and explain from these verses why God is revealing His wrath at the present time.
4. a.  What can we learn about God from the natural world, and how can this encourage your own personal worship and conversations with unbelievers?
4. b.  What can we not learn about God from nature, and how may we learn these necessary truths?

5.  Define the word “suppress.” What results of suppressing the truth do you see in your own life and what will you ask God to help you do about it? How might that impact others who suppress the truth?

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 1:21-23.

questions.questionText: 6.  From these verses, how has humanity rejected the knowledge of God that His creation reveals?
7. a.  What is the first result of rejecting God, and why is this consequence appropriate?
7. b.  What has God done about light in a dark world, and how can you bring God’s light to those around you who live in darkness? (See also John 1:4-9; 8:12; Matthew 5:14-16.)
8.  In verses 22-23, what exchange has humanity made, and how do these verses, as well as today’s world, show this exchange leads to degrading practices?

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 1:24-28.

questions.questionText: 9. a.  What truth about God do these verses indicate humanity has exchanged for a lie?
9. b.  What substitutes for God could you be worshipping or serving, and how would your life be impacted if God removed those substitutes?
10.  What are some of the reasons God links the sin of idolatry to sexual immorality? (See Genesis 1:26-27; 2:24-25; Mark 10:8-9; 1 Corinthians 6:9-11, 18-20.)
11.  What phrase occurs three times to describe God’s action, and how does this repeated phrase change your thoughts about those who seem to get away with immorality and injustice?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 1:28-32.

questions.questionText: 12.  How is a “depraved” mind different from one that does “not think it worthwhile to retain knowledge of God”?
13.  Share how God has changed your thinking about a sin of which you previously approved.
14.  What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?

LESSON/2017_3?lang=eng.name: Romans2017_3
LESSON/2017_3?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “For since the creation of the world, God’s invisible qualities – his eternal power and divine nature – have been clearly seen, being understood from what has been made, so that people are without excuse.” – Romans 1:20

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 2:1-4.

questions.questionText: 3. Why are the people in this passage without excuse, and upon what does God base His judgment?
4. What does it mean to pass judgment, and how does this differ from knowing and teaching God’s standards? Tell how you struggle with passing judgment on others.
5. How has God showered you with kindness and patience, and how do you demonstrate these godly attributes toward others?

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 2:5-16.

questions.questionText: 6. What do stubborn, unrepentant people store up for themselves, and what are you storing up? (See also Matthew 6:19-20; 12:35.)
7. a. From verses 7-11, list the results when people follow the path of good and when they follow the path of evil.
7. b. What do your actions reveal about your heart attitude toward God?
8. What standard will God use to judge people’s obedience?

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 2:17-24.

questions.questionText: 9. a. What privileges did God give the Jews, and what was their attitude toward their privileges?
9. b.  What specific privileges has He given you, and how do you sometimes demonstrate the same attitude?

10. Which of the 10 Commandments did Paul accuse the Jews of breaking? List some common ways Christians who teach others about following Jesus fail to do what He says? (See Exodus 20:1-17; Matthew 7:21-23.)
11. What happens when any religious person violates the standards they proclaim? Is there an area of your life in which you may be guilty of this?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 2:25-29.

questions.questionText: 12. a. What is circumcision, and why would this sign be a source of pride? (See Genesis 17:1-14.)
12. b. Name some outward signs people today rely on to be in right relationship with God.
13. According to this passage, what is a true Jew, and what does this mean to you?
14. What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?

LESSON/2017_4?lang=eng.name: Romans2017_4
LESSON/2017_4?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “For God does not show favoritism.” – Romans 2:11

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 3:1-4.

questions.questionText: 3. a. What expectations might the Jews in Paul’s day have had about their spiritual advantages? (See also Romans 2:6-29.) What expectations of God do you have concerning any spiritual advantages you may have?
3. b. Why was it an advantage for the Jews that God entrusted them with His very words, and how is God’s Word, the Bible, a great advantage for you?
4. Try to connect the promises God made to the Jews with Romans 3:3-4. (Some of the promises are found in Genesis 12:1-7; Deuteronomy 30:15-20; Jeremiah 31:35-37. There are several interpretations.)
5. Ultimately, who is responsible for a person’s sin and unbelief? Why? (See Psalm 51:1-6; James 1:13-14.)

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 3:5-8.

questions.questionText: 6.  What “human argument” did Paul expose as wrong, and why was God’s wrath justified?
7. What should be the believer’s attitude toward sin, and how does your attitude toward sin compare with your  actions? (Use any Bible passages you wish to support your answer.)

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 3:9-18.

questions.questionText: 8. a. From these verses, what are the promised effects of sin, and how have you seen these effects in your life?

8. b. What words in verse 13-14 reveal how seriously God views our speech? What warning do you receive about your words, and what specifically will you ask God to help you change? (See also James 3:5-10.)
9. According to verse 18, what sin appears to underlie the sins in verses 13-17, and how does this passage show this root sin is true of people in both Old and New Testament times?
10.  What does it look like to fear (have a reverent awe for) God?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 3:19-20.

questions.questionText: 11. What does Paul conclude in verses 19-20?
12. a. What does it mean to have every mouth silenced and the whole world accountable to God?
12. b. How has the study of Romans helped you to identify, confess and repent of your sin?
13.  What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?

LESSON/2017_5?lang=eng.name: Romans2017_5
LESSON/2017_5?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “As it is written: ‘There is no one righteous, not even one; there is no one who understands; there is no one who seeks God.’ ” – Romans 3:10-11

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 3:21-23.

questions.questionText: 3.  Define “righteousness.” Where does it come from, and how is it received? How does this compare with your  understanding of righteousness?
4.  What does “apart from the law” mean?

5. a.  How does the Old Testament also show the righteousness God gives is apart from the law? Why does this matter? (See Genesis 15:6; Jeremiah 31:33-34; Ezekiel 36:26-27 or any other Old Testament reference.)
5. b.  Who may receive God’s righteousness, and what is your response to His gift? (See also Romans 10:9-10, 14.)

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 3:23-24.

questions.questionText: 6.  What examples might you use from the Bible, history, current culture or your own life to help an unbeliever under-stand “all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God”?
7. a.  Define “justified.” How is justification accomplished, and why is that good news? (See also Genesis 15:6; Isaiah 53:11; 2 Corinthians 5:21.)
7. b.  Explain “the redemption that came by Christ Jesus”. What does redemption teach you about God? (For additional help see Mark 10:45; Ephesians 1:7-8; Titus 2:14; 1 Peter 1:18)
8.  How does God’s grace in justification and redemption reveal that you are loved and wanted by God? How does that impact your response to Him?

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 3:24-26.

questions.questionText: 9.  What does it mean that Jesus is a  “sacrifice of atonement” (“propitiation,” ESV)? How does this assure you that God’s justice has been satisfied? (For help see Hebrews 2:17; 1 John 2:2; 4:10; use a dictionary if you wish.)
10.  Why would God present His own Son as a sacrifice of atonement and how can you express your gratitude for such great love?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 3:25-26.

questions.questionText: 11.  How did God demonstrate His righteousness in Jesus Christ?
12.  How can you know you will never have to face God’s just punishment and with whom will you share the freedom this knowledge gives?
13.  What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?

LESSON/2017_6?lang=eng.name: Romans2017_6
LESSON/2017_6?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “This righteousness is given through faith in Jesus Christ to all who believe. There is no difference between Jew and Gentile, for all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God.” – Romans 3:22-23

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 3:27-28.

questions.questionText: 3. How do people today boast about their spirituality or relationship with God, and why is all boasting to be excluded?
4. Name some different ways people try to justify themselves before God. Which one most accurately applies to the way you live?
5. What is wrong with people’s hearts and relationships when they boast of their own righteousness, and how can you guard against self-righteousness?

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 3:27-28.

questions.questionText: 6. List various ways people today understand and use the word “faith.”

7. a.  Read Hebrews 11. Describe in your own words the kind of faith that justifies or saves a person. (You may use any Scripture references to support your answer.) List some things these believers’ faith caused them to do.
7. b. Share something your faith has recently prompted you to do.

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 3:29-30.

questions.questionText: 8.  Who are Gentiles, and why would Jews in Paul’s day look down on them? (See Romans 2:17, 23, 25. Use a  dictionary if necessary.)
9. How does the fact that “there is only one God” and one way of salvation compare with how many people  think today?
10. What truths from this passage or previous lessons could you use to respond graciously to people who say all  religions are true or there are many gods or many ways to God?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 3:31.

questions.questionText: 11.  How does faith uphold the law? (See Exodus 20:1-17; Romans 8:3-4; 13:8-10.)

12. Give examples of what goes wrong when people in the church believe they do not need to obey God’s commands and also teach others to disobey. (This thinking is called “antinomianism.”) (See also Jude 1:4.)
13.  If  God has justified you through faith, give examples of how He encourages and enables you to obey Him.  (See Romans 8:12-17, 31-34; Philippians 2:12-13; 1 John 1:5-10.)
14. What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?

LESSON/2017_7?lang=eng.name: Romans2017_7
LESSON/2017_7?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “For we maintain that a person is justified by faith apart from the works of the law.” – Romans 3:28

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 4:1-5.

questions.questionText: 3. What did Abraham believe, and how did his life show his faith and honor God? (For additional help, see Genesis 12:1-9; 13:1-18; 15:1-6, 18; 17:1-10, 23.)
4. Why do workers not consider their wages a gift from their employers?
5. a. What gift does God give all who trust Him, and what wages do people who insist on an employer-employee relationship with God earn? (See also Romans 6:23.)
5. b. Which type of relationship with God do you have? What does your life reveal about your faith and expecta- tions of God?

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 4:6-8.

questions.questionText: 6. How did David learn the truth he taught in Psalm 32, quoted in Romans 4:7-8? (See 2 Samuel 11-12; Psalm 32; 51.)
7. How could these verses help believers who struggle with guilt from past sins? (You may use other verses from Scripture.)

8. Privately and specifically, name sins God has counted against Christ instead of you. Share with your group a time you experienced the joy of forgiveness and how you will express thankfulness to Christ for taking your sin and giving you His righteousness. (See also 2 Corinthians 5:19-21.)

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 4:9-15.

questions.questionText: 9. About how long after God declared Abraham righteous did He give the sign of circumcision to Abraham and the Law to Abraham’s descendants? Why is this sequence of events important? (See Genesis 15:6, 13-18; 16:1-4, 16; 17:25-26; Galatians 3:15-18.)

10. a. What happens when people depend on their own obedience or on signs, such as circumcision, baptism or the Lord’s Supper, as a measure of their righteousness? What is the value of obedience and signs?
10. b. Briefly explain why you believe you are or are not righteous in God’s eyes.

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 4:16-25.

questions.questionText: 11. From these verses, describe the faith of Abraham and explain who Abraham’s offspring are.
12. How did Abraham face the facts of his situation, and what happened to his faith as he waited for God to fulfill  His promise?
13. What difficult situation has God used or is using to strengthen your faith?
14. What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?
15. Homiletics for group and administrative leaders: Romans 4

LESSON/2017_8?lang=eng.name: Romans2017_8
LESSON/2017_8?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “Yet he did not waver through unbelief regarding the promise of God, but was strengthened in his faith and gave glory to God, being fully persuaded that God had power to do what he had promised.” – Romans 4:20-21

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 5:1-2.

questions.questionText: 3. What does it mean to have peace with God, and how is it accomplished? How is this different from and superior to peaceful circumstances or feelings?
4. What access do believers have through Jesus Christ, and how should this privilege impact your daily life? (See also John 14:6; Ephesians 2:18; 3:12; Hebrews 4:14-16.)

5. Christians will see God’s glory in heaven. How might focusing on your “hope of the glory of God” strengthen you, comfort you or give you joy today? (See also Psalm 17:15; Matthew 5:8; 1 John 3:2; Revelation 22:3-4.)

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 5:3-5.

questions.questionText: 6. a. Why and how can believers glory (rejoice or boast) in suffering?
6. b.  How has God used your suffering to produce perseverance, character, hope and a deeper knowledge of His love in you and in those around you?
7. Why does hope not disappoint us or “put us to shame,” and what role does the Holy Spirit play in this process?

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 5:6-8.

questions.questionText: 8. a. Give three words from these verses that describe the condition of those for whom Christ died. Why is this good news?
8. b. How do these three words make clear that people cannot save themselves, and what is your personal experience of this? (See also Ephesians 2:1-9.)
9. How might these verses help you explain why Christianity is unique as compared with other religions and  philosophies?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 5:9-11.

questions.questionText: 10. List various aspects of salvation from these verses.
11. a.  Define “reconciliation.” (If needed, use a dictionary.)
11. b.  Is God reconciled to us or are we reconciled to God, and what does it reveal about God?
12. How are we saved through Christ’s life, and what words or actions will you use to boast (rejoice) in Him?  (See also Romans 4:25; 6:8-10; 8:34; or other Bible passages you may know.)
13. What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?
14. Homiletics for group and administrative leaders: Romans 5:1-11

LESSON/2017_9?lang=eng.name: Romans2017_9
LESSON/2017_9?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “Therefore, since we have been justified through faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ.” –  Romans 5:1

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 5:12-14.

questions.questionText: 3.  Read Genesis 2:15-3:24. Who was the “one man” in Romans 5:12? What warning did God give him, and what harm did his sin cause? (See also Romans 3:9-11, 23; 8:20-21; 1 Corinthians 15:22; Ephesians 2:1-3.)
4. What do most people you know believe about humanity – that all people are born good, born neutral or born  sinners? What do you believe and why?

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 5:14-19.

questions.questionText: 5. List ways Adam (“a pattern”) and Jesus Christ (“the one to come”) are the same and ways they differ. How did Jesus bring more good than all that Adam destroyed?
6. What is the “gift”? Why do verses 15-17 mention it so often, and what is your response to it?
7. What unites people to Adam, and what unites them to Christ? To whom are you united, and how do you know? (See also John 3:7-21; Romans 10:9-13; or other Bible passages.)

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 5:18-19.

questions.questionText: 8. What are some results of condemnation, and what impact do these verses have on you? (See Matthew 13:47-50;  Romans 2:8-9; Philippians 3:18-19; 2 Thessalonians 1:8-9; Revelation 20:14-15.)
9. a. What is the “one righteous act” that resulted in justification and life? (Use other verses if you wish.)
9. b. What are some results of life in Christ, and how are they evident in your life? (See John 10:28; Galatians 2:20; Ephesians 3:12; Philippians 3:20-21; Hebrews 13:20-21.)

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 5:20-21.

questions.questionText: 10. a. Why does law cause trespass (sin) to increase? (See Romans 7:7-12; Galatians 3:24.)
10. b. How do you see this principle at work in you, your family, community or country?
11. Share briefly a recent example of God’s grace overcoming the consequences of your sin.
12. What are the two reigns (kingdoms) in verse 21, and what happens to those who belong to each kingdom? (See also Colossians 1:13-14.)
13. What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?
14. Homiletics for group and administrative leaders: Romans 5:12-21

LESSON/2017_10?lang=eng.name: Romans2017_10
LESSON/2017_10?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “Consequently, just as one trespass resulted in condemnation for all people, so also one righteous act resulted in  justification and life for all people.” – Romans 5:18

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 6:1-4.

questions.questionText: 3. What thoughts in chapter 5 prompted Paul to ask the question in 6:1, and why?
4. What happens when Christians believe their sin does not matter?
5. When have you been tempted to sin because you knew God would forgive you? How might these verses strengthen you to fight sin instead?

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 6:1-4.

questions.questionText: 6. Who are “we” and “us” in these verses?  If you are part of this group, rewrite verse 2 as your own statement.
7. Describe the spiritual reality to which water baptism points. (See also Acts 1:5; 2:38; 1 Corinthians 12:13;  Galatians 3:26-27; Colossians 2:11-12.)

8.  Specifically how does Paul say believers have died to sin?  If Christ is your Savior, how have you experienced this death personally and how are you now living a new life? (See also Romans 5:12-21; 2 Corinthians 5:14-21.)

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 6:5-10.

questions.questionText: 9. From these verses, name ways believers are united with Christ.
10. What does Paul mean by “the old self ”? (See also Ephesians 4:22-24; Colossians 3:9-10.)
11. For which aspects of your union with Christ will you thank God, and where do you need His help to believe He has set you free from sin? (See also Colossians 2:11-15.)

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 6:9-11.

questions.questionText: 12. List facts about Jesus from verses 9-10. How does verse 11 connect your life with what is true of Jesus?
13. What does it look like to be dead to sin but alive to Christ: In your home? In your school, workplace or community? In your church?
14. What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?
15. Homiletics for group and administrative leaders: Romans 6:1-11

LESSON/2017_11?lang=eng.name: Romans2017_11
LESSON/2017_11?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “In the same way, count yourselves dead to sin but alive to God in Christ Jesus.” – Romans 6:11

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 6:12-14.

questions.questionText: 3. What truths in earlier chapters of Romans precede the word “therefore” in verse 12? (See previous lessons.)
4. a. List the two negative commands and the two positive commands, and explain why lasting change requires both negative and positive actions. (See also Ephesians 4:22-24; Colossians 3:9-10.)
4. b.  Give specific ways you are tempted to offer any part of yourself to sin and ways to offer every part of yourself to God.
5. How does God’s promise in verse 14 encourage you in light of the commands in verses 12-13? (See also Romans 5:20-21.)

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 6:15-16.

questions.questionText: 6. How do the questions in verses 1 and 15 differ, and how are they alike?
7. a. What does it mean to “be a slave to sin” or a “slave to righteousness”?
7. b. Because we are slaves to the one we obey, would you describe yourself now as a slave to sin or a slave to righteousness, and why?

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 6:17-18.

questions.questionText: 8. Compare and contrast obedience from the heart and following rules. Which describes your actions?
9. What is “the pattern of teaching” Paul says “claims the allegiance” of believers? (See Romans 6:1-14 or other Scripture passages.)
10. If Christ has set you free from sin, what are some aspects of your freedom for which you thank God?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 6:19-23.

questions.questionText: 11. List ways in which people want to be free and why these things are or are not true freedom.
12. What are the results of being a slave to sin, and what are the results of being a slave to God?
13. a. How have you personally experienced sin’s wages, which lead to death? If you are a believer, how has God used those things for His glory and your good?
13. b. What attitudes and behaviors are produced in you as you meditate on God’s gift of eternal life?
14. What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?
15. Homiletics for group and administrative leaders: Romans 6:12-23

LESSON/2017_12?lang=eng.name: Romans2017_12
LESSON/2017_12?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “For the wages of sin is death, but the gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord.” – Romans 6:23

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 7:1-6.

questions.questionText: 3. How do these verses build on the truth of the believer’s union with Christ? (See Romans 6:1-11, 14.)
4. a. From what does Christ’s death free believers, to whom do they now belong and what is their purpose?
4. b. If you are a believer, how are you living out your God-given purpose and freedom, especially in your relation- ships in work, family, community life, etc.?

5. Contrast “fruit for God” and “the new way of the Spirit” with “fruit for death” and “the old way of the written code.” (See also John 15:1-5 and Galatians 5:16-23.) Where do you see these patterns in your life?

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 7:7-13. Note: Christians differ about whether Romans 7:7-25 refers to Paul’s life before or after Jesus saved him.

questions.questionText: 6. From verses 7-13, what does the law do for people, and how does sin use the law against people?
7. How does sin deceive you and harm your mind, emotions or body? What does sin reveal about your understanding of God and how will you respond to what He is showing you?

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 7:14-20.

questions.questionText: 8. Explain how the law is “spiritual” and why Paul describes himself as “unspiritual.”
9. How would you explain Paul’s struggle in these verses to your family or others you want to help grow in Christ?
10. What do you do that you do not want to do, and what good do you not do that you really want to do?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 7:21-25.

questions.questionText: 11. Describe Paul’s distress over sin in these verses.
12. a. How does Paul answer the question he asked in verse 24?
12. b. Why is Paul’s answer the only true help for those who live under the burden of the law as well as those who tend to lawless living?
13. Can you share a time distress over sin led you to desperate prayer, and how might Romans 6 and 7 help you pray about your ongoing struggle with sin?
14. What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?
15. Homiletics for group and administrative leaders: Romans 7

LESSON/2017_13?lang=eng.name: Romans2017_13
LESSON/2017_13?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “What a wretched man I am! Who will rescue me from this body that is subject to death? Thanks be to God, who  delivers me through Jesus Christ our Lord!” – Romans 7:24-25a

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 8:1-4.

questions.questionText: 3. a.  From your study of Romans 1-7, how would you explain Romans 8:1? What is the significance of “now” and “no condemnation”? (For additional help, see John 3:16-17; 5:24.)
3. b. How does Romans 8:1 affect the way you view yourself and others? What changes will you ask God to make in your thoughts or actions?
4.  How does this passage show that the whole Trinity (Father, Son and Holy Spirit) works to save sinners?
5.  Because those in Christ are no longer under law, why and how do they fulfill the law’s righteous requirements?  (See also John 14:15-21; 16:5-15.)

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 8:5-11.

questions.questionText: 6.  Name the two basic groups of people these verses describe and contrast their mindsets and lives.
7.  How can you recognize a mind set on what the Spirit desires? (See also Galatians 5:22-23; Colossians 3:1-4.) Would others say that is true of you?
8.  According to verses 9-11, what things are true of everyone in whom the Spirit of God (also called the Spirit of Christ) lives, and how do these truths encourage you today?

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 8:12-14.

questions.questionText: 9.  According to these verses, what is a Christian’s obligation and why? (See also 2 Corinthians 7:1; Philippians  3:10-14; 1 John 3:1-3.)
10. a.  How can God’s children “put to death the misdeeds of the body”? (See also Galatians 5:13-26; Colossians 3:5-17.)
10. b.  What does the phrase “put to death” teach about the attitude God’s children are to have toward their sin, and where do you need the Holy Spirit’s help to change your attitude and actions?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 8:14-17.

questions.questionText: 11.  List privileges of adoption into God’s family. (See also Romans 8:29.)

12.   From the following verses, give additional benefits of being God’s child and, if you are a believer, express how you have experienced these benefits.  (Matthew 6:7-8; 10:29-31; Hebrews 12:7-11; 1 John 3:1-3)
13.  How might these truths help you or others who struggle with doubt of God’s fatherly love?
14.  What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?
15. Homiletics for group and administrative leaders: Romans 8:1-17

LESSON/2017_14?lang=eng.name: Romans2017_14
LESSON/2017_14?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “Therefore, there is now no condemnation for those who are in Christ Jesus.” – Romans 8:1

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 8:17-18.

questions.questionText: 3. What was Paul’s experience with suffering, and how does this affect your understanding of these verses and encourage you in your suffering?  (See 2 Corinthians 4:7-18; 6:4-10; 11:23-28 or other verses you may know.)
4.a. What does the word “glory” mean? (Use a dictionary for help.)
4.b. Give various aspects of our “glory” from the following verses:  2 Corinthians 3:18
4.c. Philippians 3:20-21
4.d.  Colossians 1:27
4.e.  2 Thessalonians 2:13-14
4.f. Hebrews 2:10

5. What is the relationship between suffering and glory, and what hope does this give you for yourself, your church or for suffering believers worldwide?  (See references given above or other verses you may know.)

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 8:19-22.

questions.questionText: 6. What does Paul mean by “creation” in this passage?
7. List ways you see the creation subject to frustration and decay today. (See also Genesis 1:27-2:1; 3:17-19.)

8. When and how will creation be liberated? (See 2 Peter 3:13; Revelation 21:1 or other verses you may know.) How do these truths help you distinguish proper creation care from idolizing nature or trusting in people’s efforts to renew the planet?

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 8:23-25.

questions.questionText: 9. Who and what groan in these verses, and why do they groan? (See also Romans 8:22, 26.)
10. a. For what do Christians hope, and how are they to wait?
10. b. For what are you waiting and hoping, and why?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 8:26-27.

questions.questionText: 11.a. From these verses, share various ways the Holy Spirit works in a believer’s life and at least one way He has been working in yours. Romans 8:26-27
11.c. Acts 1:8
11.e. Ephesians 4:3-4
11.f Ephesians 6:17
11.g. 1 Corinthians 2:12
12.a. What is meant by “the Spirit intercedes for God’s people in accordance with the will of God”?
12.b. Who, besides the Holy Spirit, intercedes for you today, and for whom do you pray? (See Romans 8:34 or  other verses you may know.)
13. What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?
14. Homiletics for group and administrative leaders: Romans 8:18-27

LESSON/2017_15?lang=eng.name: Romans2017_15
LESSON/2017_15?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “I consider that our present sufferings are not worth comparing with the glory that will be revealed in us.” – Romans 8:18

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 8:28.

questions.questionText: 3. What is the “good” that God works for His people in all things? (See also Romans 8:29-39.)
4. a. Put Romans 8:28 in your own words. What assurances does this verse offer the believer in every situation?
4. b. How might you pray when struggling with things that you wonder how God will use for good?
5. What do you learn about God’s attributes and character from Romans 8:28, and how does this challenge or comfort you?

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 8:29-30.

questions.questionText: 6.a.  Briefly explain the following concepts. (For help, see John 6:37, 44; Romans 1:6-7; 3:22-26; 8:17-21;  Ephesians 1:4-5, 11 or other Bible passages.)  Foreknew
6.b.  Predestined
6.c.  Called
6.d.   Justified
6.e.   Glorified
6.f. What does Romans 8:29-30 reveal about God, and why is it good news?

7.  What are some ways God works to conform believers to the image of His Son? What are some reasons many professing believers do not act like Jesus? (See also Romans 5:3-5; 2 Timothy 3:12, 15-16; Hebrews 5:7-8 or other Bible passages.)
8. How do you see God at work in your life to make you more Christlike?

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 8:31-35.

questions.questionText: 9. List the questions and answers in verses 31-35. What conclusions can you draw based on these questions and answers?
10. With which of the previous questions are you struggling, and how do the answers encourage you?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 8:35-39.

questions.questionText: 11.  Why does Paul quote Psalm 44:22 to answer the questions verse 35 asks? (See also John 16:33.)
12.  a.  How do “all these things” in verses 35-37 relate to “all things” in verses 28 and 32?
12. b.  How has a deeper understanding of Christ’s love helped you in a specific difficulty this year?
13. List things in your life or world events that tempt you to worry or prompt anger and impatience. Use your list to rewrite verses 38-39 as your own statement of confidence in God’s love for you.
14. What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?
15. Homiletics for group and administrative leaders: Romans 8:28-39

LESSON/2017_16?lang=eng.name: Romans2017_16
LESSON/2017_16?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “He who did not spare his own Son, but gave him up for us all — how will he not also, along with him, graciously give us all things?” – Romans 8:32

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 9:1-5.

questions.questionText: 3.  What truth does Paul affirm? Why is Paul grieving for the people of Israel and how is he like Moses and Jesus? (For additional help see Exodus 32:30-32; Luke 19:41-44; John 10:11; Romans 9:1-29.)
4. a. Explain what “cursed” means in Romans 9:3 and whether any believer might ever be “cut off” from Christ. What do you think is Paul’s point? (See also Romans 8:1, 35, 38-39.)
4. b. How does Paul’s love for the unbelieving people of Israel model the way believers should respond to unbelievers?
5. Consider the spiritual advantages God has given you. What are their benefits? How are they sometimes squandered?

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 9:6-13.

questions.questionText: 6. a. How is God true to His Word despite the unbelief of the majority of the Israelite people?
6. b. What examples does Paul give to prove that physical birth never automatically makes anyone God’s child? (See also Romans 2:28-29.)
7. How do these verses show salvation is by grace and not human effort? What hope does this give you for your unbelieving family members, friends or co-workers?

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 9:14-21.

questions.questionText: 8. What does Paul’s use of Bible history reveal about God and how He elects to work out His righteous and holy will? How does this compare with your understanding?  (See also Exodus 7:3, 13; 8:32; 14:4.)
9. a. From verses 20-21, explain in your own words the problem with people accusing God of injustice. (See also Isaiah 29:16; 64:8; Jeremiah 18:6; 2 Timothy 2:20.)
9. b. Give examples of how people today (perhaps even you) use similar reasons to excuse sin or accuse God of injustice.
10. How has God shown you mercy when your heart was hard, and how have you responded to Him?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 9:22-29.

questions.questionText: 11. In verses 22-24, how and why does God demonstrate His power and mercy?
12.  What about the riches of God’s glory move you to prayer, praise or practical actions? (See also Ephesians 1:7-8, 18-23; 2:1-10.)
13. What do you learn about God’s mercy and grace to Jews and Gentiles from the Hosea and Isaiah quotations?  (See also Romans 11:3-6.)
14. What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?
15. Homiletics for group and administrative leaders: Romans 9:1-29

LESSON/2017_17?lang=eng.name: Romans2017_17
LESSON/2017_17?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “What if he did this to make the riches of his glory known to the objects of his mercy, whom he prepared in advance for glory – even us, whom he also called, not only from the Jews but also from the Gentiles?” – Romans 9:23-24

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes with references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 9:30-33.

questions.questionText: 3. What was the difference in the way the Gentiles and Israel approached righteousness? What were the results?
4. How is daily pursuing righteous behavior different from striving for righteous standing? What role does faith play?
5. Who is “the stumbling stone”? What about “the stumbling stone” causes people to stumble or fall?

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 10:1-4.

questions.questionText: 6. Why would Paul so strongly desire the Israelites be saved? How has God called you to pray for and minister tothose you desire to be saved?

7. What knowledge did the Israelites lack that caused their zeal to be misdirected? What does zealous behaviorwithout true knowledge of Jesus look like in today’s world? (Focus on behaviors without naming groups.)
8. Explain Romans 10:4 in your own words. (You may want to read additional Bible translations to help you.)

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 10:5-9.

questions.questionText: 9. What conclusions does Paul make in light of these verses? (Note: Romans 10:5-7 can be interpreted in  various ways.)
10. What must a person do to be saved?
11. How would you take each phrase of verse 9 and explain its meaning and importance to an unbeliever?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 10:10-13

questions.questionText: 12. Share different aspects of the word “heart” from the following references: Matthew 6:21; 12:34; Romans 1:21-22; Galatians 4:6. As you meditate on these verses, what is God showing you about your heart?
13. How does verse 13 relate to and clarify verse 11? According to these verses, to whom is salvation available?
14. When did you (or will you) call on the name of the Lord for salvation?
15. What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?
16. Homiletics for discussion and administrative leaders: Romans 9:30-10:13

LESSON/2017_18?lang=eng.name: Romans Lesson 182017_18
LESSON/2017_18?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “If you declare with your mouth, ‘Jesus is Lord,’ and believe in your heart that God raised him from the dead, you will be saved.” – Romans 10:9

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 10:14-15.

questions.questionText: 3. How does Paul describe the steps to believing in Jesus Christ in verses 14-15?  Share your personal progression through the steps to believing in Jesus.
4. Summarize the “good news” from your study of Romans.
5. What is your role in sharing the good news with family, friends and the world?

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 10:14-15.

questions.questionText: 6.a. Give at least one point about the proclamation of the gospel from each reference.   Matthew 28:18-20
6.b. Acts 1:8
6.d. Romans 15:20
6.e. 2 Corinthians 2:12-14
6.f. 2 Corinthians 10:15-16
7. To whom does Paul’s quotation from Isaiah 52:7 refer? Why were their feet beautiful?
8. How is God calling you to take His message of grace into places filled with despair?

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 10:16-17.

questions.questionText: 9. From a human perspective, why do people not respond positively to the good news when they hear it?
10. According to verse 17, from where does faith come? What does this teach about the importance of studying the Bible?
11. Share a time the Bible brought forth or strengthened your faith?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 10:18-21.

questions.questionText: 12. Try to describe Paul’s logic in verses 18-21. How would you explain the differences in hearing, understanding and believing?
13. To whom were Moses and Isaiah referring in verses 19-20?
14. Where has God strategically placed you to share the Bible’s truths? How might you encourage someone today?
15. What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?
16. Homiletics for discussion and administrative leaders: Romans 10:14–21

LESSON/2017_19?lang=eng.name: Romans Lesson 192017_19
LESSON/2017_19?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “Consequently, faith comes from hearing the message, and the message is heard through the word about Christ.” – Romans 10:17

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 11:1-10.

questions.questionText: 3. Explain Paul’s reasoning as to why God has not rejected the Jewish people. How do Paul’s testimony and Elijah’s experience strengthen his explanation?
4. What is a remnant? How is the remnant chosen?
5. What is the connection between grace and the elect?  How does that impact your understanding of election?

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 11:1-10.

questions.questionText: 6. From verse 7, what did Israel seek? Why did they not obtain it? (See Romans 9:31-33)
7.a. How do the following passages help you understand verses 7-10?  Isaiah 29:10-14
7.c. Matthew 13:12-15

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 11:11-24.

questions.questionText: 8. Explain Paul’s reasoning in verses 11-16. What good has come from Israel’s rejection?
9. Without pressing the illustration too far, give in a few words about the point Paul made in verses 17-24. How does this passage address the boasting believer?
10. How has God demonstrated both kindness and sternness in your life? What have been the results?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 11:25-32.

questions.questionText: 11. What could “all Israel” mean? Which interpretation seems most likely based on what you know about God and His Word? (There are several interpretations.)
12. What will happen to Israel?  How can we be sure?
13. What do these verses reveal about God’s work and character? How do these truths comfort or challenge you?
14. How did God show mercy to both Jews and Gentiles? Explain in your own words why all people need the mercy of God.
15. What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?
16. Homiletics for discussion and administrative leaders: Romans 11:1-32.

LESSON/2017_20?lang=eng.name: Romans Lesson 202017_20
LESSON/2017_20?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “I do not want you to be ignorant of this mystery, brothers and sisters, so that you may not be conceited: Israel has experienced a hardening in part until the full number of the Gentiles has come in.” – Romans 11:25

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 11:33-36.

questions.questionText: 3. Paul breaks into praise to God in verses 33-36. What reasons expressed in verses 25-32 would cause him to do this?
4. In chapter 11, how did Paul describe God’s plan for saving the Gentiles?
5. What has God done recently that would cause you to break into praise of Him?

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 11:33-34.

questions.questionText: 6. For which attributes does Paul praise God in verse 33?
7.a. Share aspects of these attributes from the following verses.  How do these verses relate to your present circumstances?  1 Kings 8:39
7.b. Job 9:4
7.d. Psalm 147:4
7.e. Proverbs 3:19
8. Try to trace God’s wise ways in one area of your life. (Examples include your education, employment, family or other.)

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 11:33-34.

questions.questionText: 9. What is Paul asking in verse 34? What is the answer?
10. How do people’s perceptions of themselves differ from the biblical perspective given in these verses? (See Job 38:1-7; Job 42:1-6; Psalm 8:1-9; Isaiah 40:13-28.)
11. How do these attributes of God comfort or challenge you? In what area of your life are you clinging to or forgetting these attributes?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 11:35-36.

questions.questionText: 12.  What has God given to people in general and to you specifically?  How will you respond to all God has given you? (See Genesis 1:27-30; John 3:16; Acts 17:24-28 or any other Scripture.)
13. What can people give to God? (See Job 35:7-8, 41:11 or any other Scripture.)
14. How might people place God under obligation to repay them today (knowingly or unknowingly)?
15. How are all things from God, through God and to God?
16. For what reason did God create the universe? (See Isaiah 43:7; Ephesians 1:5-10; Revelation 4:11.)
17. What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?
18. Homiletics for discussion and administrative leaders: Romans 11:33-36

LESSON/2017_21?lang=eng.name: Romans Lesson 212017_21
LESSON/2017_21?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “For from him and through him and for him are all things. To him be the glory forever! Amen.” – Romans 11:36

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 12:1-2.

questions.questionText: 3.  What specific points from Romans was Paul thinking about as he started this section with the word “therefore”?
4. What are Christians to do as a result of the truths learned through the Romans study?
5.  What qualities or behaviors should make Christians different from the world around them? Tell about a Christian who has had a profound influence in your life.

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 12:1.

questions.questionText: 6.a.  What do you learn about God and His mercy from the following verses? Romans 9:15
6.b. Romans 9:23
6.c. Ephesians 2:4-5
6.d. 1 Peter 1:3
7  How has God shown His mercy to your country, to your family and to you?
8.  Define “sacrifice.” Compare and contrast the Old Testament sacrifices of animals with the kind of sacrifice Paul is urging Christians to be. (See Leviticus 16; Hebrews 10:1-10; and Romans 6:3-4.)
9.  Share both ordinary and extraordinary examples in which people today offer their bodies as living sacrifices.

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 12:2; Galatians 1:3-5; and Ephesians 2:1-2.

questions.questionText: 10.  How is the word “world” used in this context?
11.  How is the pattern of this world described in 1 John 2:15-17? How would you describe the pattern of this world in your own words?
12.  In what ways has the pattern of the world crept into your thinking, choices, habits, outlook, relationships or priorities?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 12:1-2.

questions.questionText: 13.  According to Romans 12:2; 2 Corinthians 3:18 and Philippians 2:13, how is a person transformed?
14.  How does a person renew their mind? How are you helping to renew the minds of others including the next generation?
15.  How does Paul describe God’s will? How does this differ from the world’s (and some Christians’) ideas of God’s will?
16.a.  What do these verses teach about God’s good, pleasing and perfect will? John 14:15
16.b. 2 Corinthians 10:5
16.c. 1 Thessalonians 4:3-7
16.e. 1 Peter 2:15
16.f. 1 Peter 3:17

17. How has your understanding of God’s will changed or developed through this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life? No homiletics for administrative and discussion leaders

LESSON/2017_22?lang=eng.name: Romans Lesson 222017_22
LESSON/2017_22?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “Therefore, I urge you, brothers and sisters, in view of God’s mercy, to offer your bodies as a living sacrifice, holy and pleasing to God – this is your true and proper worship. Do not conform to the pattern of this world, but be transformed by the renewing of your mind. Then you will be able to test and approve what God’s will is – his good, pleasing and perfect will.” – Romans 12:1-2

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 12:3.

questions.questionText: 3. On what basis does Paul give his instructions? Why is that important?
4. What warning does he give? What possible errors can occur as we evaluate ourselves?
5. How does the phrase “measure of faith” guide a believer’s self-evaluation and evaluation of others?
6. Why is it important to have a proper evaluation of yourself before relating to others in the church?  What is God revealing to you about the way you relate to others?

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 12:4-5.

questions.questionText: 7. To what does Paul compare Christians? How does this illustration help you understand the way Christians are to relate to one another?
8. List some ways each member of the body belongs to all the other members. List some ways each member of the body has individual responsibilities.

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 12:4-5 and Ephesians 4:1-6

questions.questionText: 9. According to Scripture, who comprises the body of Christ? What unites the body of Christ?
10. What instructions does Paul give to maintain unity within local congregations and in the universal Church?
11. How are you contributing to, or eroding, unity within the body of Christ in your local congregation or in the universal Church?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 12:6-8.

questions.questionText: 12.a. Share truths concerning God’s gifts to Christians from the following verses: 1 Corinthians 7:7b
12.b. 1 Corinthians 12:4-6
12.c. Ephesians 4:11-13
13.  List the seven gifts in these verses. Write how each should be exercised along with specific ways this can be done in a local church.
14. Which of the gifts has God given you, and what opportunities has He given you to use His gifts?
15. What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?
16. Homiletics for group and administrative leaders: Romans 12:3-8

LESSON/2017_23?lang=eng.name: Romans Lesson 232017_23
LESSON/2017_23?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “So in Christ we, though many, form one body, and each member belongs to all the others.” – Romans 12:5

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 12:9-13.

questions.questionText: 3. What does Paul want you to keep in mind as you read these verses? How might remembering help you obey these commands? (See Romans 12:1-2.)
4. Compare Paul’s description of love with the popular view of love in your culture. How does hating what is evil relate to sincere love?
5.a. Compare the Bible’s description of evil with the popular view of evil in your culture.  Proverbs 8:13
5.b. Proverbs 13:5
5.c. Ecclesiastes 3:8
5.d. Isaiah 61:8
5.e. Amos 5:15

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 12:9-13.

questions.questionText: 6. Which individuals or groups is it hard for you to honor above yourself? Why?
7. Put verse 11 in your own words. How is it relevant to your current circumstances?
8. Which of Paul’s commands in Romans 12:9-13 is hardest for you to obey? Why?

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 12:14-16.

questions.questionText: 9. How does a person bless persecutors? Whom might you come alongside and bless? (See Matthew 5:44; Luke 6:27-28 or any other Scriptures.)
10. What strategies for healthy relationships are found in these verses? What opportunities is God giving you to practice these commands?
11. How does pride destroy relationships? Share an example of how humility has mended or restored relationships.
12. How have you been helped by someone who has come alongside you to weep, grieve or mourn with you?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 12:17-21.

questions.questionText: 13. Share ways people repay evil for evil today. Which ones are tempting to you?
14. Give examples from Scripture of those who did not repay evil for evil. What were the results?
15. What is the believer’s responsibility to their enemies? What does Scripture promise God will do?
16. How can a person live the kind of life Paul is commanding in Romans 12:9-21?
17. What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?
18. Homiletics for group and administrative leaders: Romans 12:9-21

LESSON/2017_24?lang=eng.name: Romans Lesson 242017_24
LESSON/2017_24?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “Love must be sincere. Hate what is evil; cling to what is good.” – Romans 12:9

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 13:1-5.

questions.questionText: 3.  Define “be subject to” or “submit.” Who is to submit to governing authorities, and why?
4.  Give reasons people struggle with submitting to authority? Which is your greatest struggle?
5.  Give examples of when refusing to submit to governing authority is acceptable in God’s eyes? (See Daniel 3 and 6; Acts 5:29)

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 13:1-5.

questions.questionText: 6.  When you refuse to submit to moral and legal authority, against whom are you ultimately rebelling?
7. How does respect for authority glorify God?
8. How is God convicting you regarding these verses?

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 13:3-5.

questions.questionText: 9.  How are rulers God’s servants for good, even if they are evil? What comfort and confidence can you have when you receive evil instead of good from a leader?
10.  What reasons does Paul give for submitting to authorities? Can you think of other reasons?
11.  What kind of example do you set for your children and others who watch your response to governing authorities?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 13:6-7.

questions.questionText: 12.  What did Jesus say about paying taxes? (See Luke 20:22-25.)
13.  What are the purposes of taxes? What should be your attitude toward paying them?
14.a. From the following verses, list those to whom we are to show respect and honor.  What are some specific ways you can show respect or honor to these people?  Exodus 20:12
14.b. Leviticus 19:32
14.c. 1 Timothy 5:17
14.d. 1 Timothy 6:15b-16
15. How can you show honor and respect to someone whose decisions and character differ from yours?
16.  What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?
17. Homiletics for discussion and administrative leaders:  Romans 13:1-7

LESSON/2017_25?lang=eng.name: Romans Lesson 252017_25
LESSON/2017_25?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “Let everyone be subject to the governing authorities, for there is no authority except that which God has established. The authorities that exist have been established by God.” – Romans 13:1

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 13:8-10 with Romans 12:9-21; 1 Corinthians 13:1-8.

questions.questionText: 3. Why can Christians never fully satisfy the continuing debt to love one another?
4. Compare and contrast legalistic versus loving obedience to the commands in verse 9. Which one do you lean toward?
5. Whom is it that you struggle to love? What does that reveal about them and you?
6.  How would you explain “love is the fulfillment of the law”?

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 13:11-12.

questions.questionText: 7.  What does Paul mean by “salvation” and “the day is almost here”? What is Paul’s motive in reminding believers our salvation is nearer now?
8.  How does the Bible describe this “present time” as the Lord’s return draws nearer? (Use any Bible verses, such as Galatians 1:4; Luke 19:44.)
9.  List ways you see Christians slumbering presently. In what ways might you be slumbering?

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 13:12-14.

questions.questionText: 10. How has your culture normalized behaviors the Bible calls indecent?
11.  Using verse 13 as help, what does behaving decently look like?
12. How is God convicting you regarding these verses?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 13:12-14.

questions.questionText: 13.  What is the “armor of light”? (Use Ephesians 6:10-18 and Galatians 5:22-23 to help you.)
14.  How does knowing Jesus is Light help you understand His character and works? (See John 8:12; 1 John 1:5-7 or any other Scriptures you may know.)
15.  How will you clothe yourself with the Lord Jesus Christ instead of gratifying the desires of the sinful nature?
16.  What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?
17. Homiletics for discussion and administrative leaders: Romans 13:8-14

LESSON/2017_26?lang=eng.name: Romans Lesson 262017_26
LESSON/2017_26?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “Rather, clothe yourselves with the Lord Jesus Christ, and do not think about how to gratify the desires of the flesh.”  – Romans 13:14

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 14:1-8.

questions.questionText: 3. How does Paul encourage weaker and stronger believers to respond to one another?
4.  What types of disputable practices are mentioned in the passage? What distinguishes a disputable practice from a forbidden practice?
5. What similar standard and conviction do both the weaker and stronger believers share?

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 14:9-12.

questions.questionText: 6. Which practices are you willing to forego for the sake of a brother or sister in Christ?
7. What is the reason we should not judge or look down on our fellow believers?
8. What will happen at God’s judgment seat? Why is that a reason not to judge others now?

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 14:13-18.

questions.questionText: 9. From these verses, share several responsibilities Christians have toward fellow believers.
10. Why was Paul able to say in verse 14 that no food is unclean in itself? What makes food unclean for a particular person?
11. How does a believer cause another believer to stumble today?
12. How does Paul describe the kingdom of God? Why does Paul make this distinction?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 14:19-23.

questions.questionText: 13. How might too much concern over disputable matters destroy the work of God?
14. What are the best practices when dealing with other believers and disputable matters?
15. What conclusion does Paul draw for stronger and weaker believers in disputable matters?
16. What behavior will you seek to change in yourself with God’s help because of studying this lesson?
17. What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?
18. Homiletics for discussion and administrative leaders: Romans 14

LESSON/2017_27?lang=eng.name: Romans Lesson 272017_27
LESSON/2017_27?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “For the kingdom of God is not a matter of eating and drinking, but of righteousness, peace and joy in the Holy Spirit.” – Romans 14:17

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 15:1-6.

questions.questionText: 3. Share some of the privileges and some of the responsibilities of Christians.
4. How does pleasing our neighbors to build them up differ from “people-pleasing”?
5. Share an example from Scripture of Jesus Christ not living to please Himself. How is that relevant to you?
6. How would you describe people who live to please themselves? What similarities and differences do you share with that description?

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 15:4-6.

questions.questionText: 7.  What are several benefits that come from studying Scripture? How have you realized these benefits through your study of Romans?
8. How does a “spirit of unity” differ from uniformity or agreement on all matters? With what groups or individual believers do you struggle to uphold unity?
9. How does Christian unity glorify God? (See 1 Corinthians 12:12-27; Ephesians 4:1-16; Colossians 1:15-20.)

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 15:7-13.

questions.questionText: 10. Why is it important for believers to accept other believers? How does Christ’s acceptance of you help you in accepting others?
11. Which Old Testament verses are quoted in Romans 15:9-12? What is the subject of these quotations?
12.  a.  What is the significance of Paul using Old Testament references to illustrate unity between the Jews and  Gentiles in Christ?
12. b.  How does this understanding help you re-evaluate fellow believers with whom you struggle to be unified?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 15:13.

questions.questionText: 13. What is the relationship between trust and hope? (See also 1 Timothy 1:1; Hebrews 6:18-19; Hebrews 11:1 or any other verses for help.)
14. What does the relationship between trust and hope teach you about God? How does this comfort or challenge you?
15. For whom will you pray the blessings of Romans 15:13?
16. What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?
17. Homiletics for discussion and administrative leaders: Romans 15:1-13

LESSON/2017_28?lang=eng.name: Romans Lesson 282017_28
LESSON/2017_28?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “May the God of hope fill you with all joy and peace as you trust in him, so that you may overflow with hope by the power of the Holy Spirit.” – Romans 15:13

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 15:14-16.

questions.questionText: 3. For what three things does Paul commend his readers? How will you encourage fellow believers this week?
4. How do you reconcile Paul’s commendations with his prior warnings and instructions? (See Romans 12:1-15:13.)
5. Describe the role of a priest in the Bible. (Use Scripture or a Bible dictionary.) In verse 16, how does Paul describe his “priestly duty” and the results?

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 15:17-21.

questions.questionText: 6. How does what Paul glories in compare with the things in which your culture rejoices or boasts?
7.  Whom did Paul credit for his success with the Gentiles? In what area of your life are you claiming success when it rightfully belongs to God? (See Deuteronomy 8:17.)
8. How do Paul’s aim and ambition in sharing the gospel compare with yours?
9. What opportunities is God giving you to share the gospel?

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 15:22-29.

questions.questionText: 10.  In verses 22-24, what did Paul long to do, and why did his longing go unfulfilled?
11.  What does this reveal about both Paul’s and your understandings of pursuing personal fulfillment?
12.  What two points does Paul make about the financial gift he was taking to Jerusalem? What principles about giving can you draw from these two points?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 15:30-33 with Acts 20:22-23.

questions.questionText: 13.  What dangers was Paul facing as he went to Jerusalem?
14. What did Paul ask for in his struggle? What does this communicate about Paul’s view of prayer?
15.  What specific prayer requests did Paul ask for himself and with what goal?
16. Paul could have chosen any attribute of God for verse 33. What might have been his reason to choose “God of peace”? In what area of your life will you ask the God of peace to minister to you?
17. What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?
18. Homiletics for discussion and administrative leaders: Romans 15:14-33

LESSON/2017_29?lang=eng.name: Romans Lesson 292017_29
LESSON/2017_29?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “Therefore I glory in Christ Jesus in my service to God.” – Romans 15:17

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. What was meaningful to you in the lecture?
2. What help did you receive from the notes?

two.title: SECOND DAY: Read Romans 16:1-16.

questions.questionText: 3. Why would Paul include this list of people?
4. What does this list reveal about Paul’s ministry? What principles for Christian ministry are revealed through this list?
5. According to these verses, what are some of the ways people loved and supported Paul? What are some of the ways God has provided for you through others?
6. Which of all these people interests you the most? Why?

three.title: THIRD DAY: Read Romans 16:17-20.

questions.questionText: 7. What does Paul’s warning reveal about Christian ministry?
8. According to these verses, how are divisive and deceptive people recognizable? What should Christians do about them?
9. Give practical examples of what it looks like to be “wise about what is good and innocent about what is evil.”
10. What assurances does Paul offer in verse 20? How does this give you hope in your present circumstances?

four.title: FOURTH DAY: Read Romans 16:20-25.

questions.questionText: 11. What do you learn about the people who are with Paul?

12. Who is on your list of people who have supported and encouraged you in life or your Christian service? How will you encourage them this week? 13 What does this teach you about the value of relationships in life or Christian ministry?
13. What does this teach you about the value of relationships in life or Christian ministry?

five.title: FIFTH DAY: Read Romans 16:25-27.

questions.questionText: 14. Put verses 25-27 in your own words.
15. From your study of Romans, what is the message Paul proclaimed about Jesus Christ?
16. What was the mystery to which Paul referred in verse 25? (See Ephesians 3:2-6 and Colossians 1:27.)
17. How will you give glory to God for all He has done in history and in your own personal life this year?
18. What have you learned about God in this week’s study? How may your group pray for you as you make this truth a part of your life?
19. Homiletics for discussion and administrative leaders: Romans 16.

LESSON/2017_30?lang=eng.name: Romans2017_30
LESSON/2017_30?lang=eng.memoryVerse: “To the only wise God be glory forever through Jesus Christ! Amen.” – Romans 16:27

one.title: FIRST DAY:

questions.questionText: 1. What did you learn about God through the study of Romans, and what difference has that made in your life?

two.title: SECOND DAY:

questions.questionText: 2. What did you learn about yourself during the study, and how did God use that to draw you closer to Him?

three.title: THIRD DAY:

questions.questionText: 3. In what ways did you experience God changing your thoughts, attitudes, desires and actions this year? How did you see Him work in the lives of the children you bring to BSF?

four.title: FOURTH DAY:

questions.questionText: 4. How has your relationship with Jesus Christ changed this year, and what impact has that had on your relationships with others?

five.title: FIFTH DAY:

questions.questionText: 5. Now that you have completed the study of Romans, what do you think God’s plan for you includes?
6. What do you want to tell others about God’s work in your life during the study of Romans? Who might need that encouragement to trust Jesus at this time?
